questionList.questionText:
A 35-year-old, previously healthy woman comes to the office due to 3 days of fever and malaise.  The patient's symptoms started after she returned from a 2-week vacation in the Caribbean islands.  For the past day, she has also had marked pain in her hand and wrist joints.  The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs and is in a monogamous relationship with her fiancé.  Temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min.  Examination reveals clear lung fields, normal heart sounds, and no murmurs.  The abdomen is soft and nontender with no hepatosplenomegaly.  She has a macular skin rash on her trunk and extremities and mild cervical lymphadenopathy.  There are no oral ulcers.  Musculoskeletal examination is notable for swelling and tenderness of bilateral hand, wrist, and ankle joints.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hematocrit38%
Platelets120,000/mm3
Leukocytes2,900/mm3
Neutrophils82%
Lymphocytes10%
Creatinine, serum0.8 mg/dL
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)32 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)24 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Chikungunya virus infection

Epidemiology

  • Tropical/subtropical parts of the Caribbean region, Central/South America, Africa & Asia
  • Vector: Aedes mosquitoes (also transmit dengue, yellow fever & Zika viruses)

Manifestations

  • Incubation period: 3-7 days
  • High fever & severe polyarthralgia (almost always present)
  • Headache, myalgia, conjunctivitis, maculopapular rash
  • Lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia, transaminitis

Management

  • Supportive care (initial symptoms usually resolve in 7-10 days)
  • Chronic arthralgia/arthritis frequently occurs (may require methotrexate)

This patient visited the Caribbean islands and subsequently developed fever, rash, and severe polyarthritis, likely indicating chikungunya, an alphavirus infection transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.  Outbreaks are common in tropical and subtropical regions (eg, Caribbean, Africa, Asia, Indian/Pacific Oceanic islands) during the rainy seasons, and travelers may return to their home countries with the illness.

Manifestations typically include high fever; diffuse maculopapular rash; and symmetric, progressive joint pain that is severe enough to interfere with daily activities.  Joint symptoms begin in the distal small joints of the hands and feet but may affect proximal joints over time.  Transient lymphopenia and thrombocytopenia often occur.

Although fever and rash resolve spontaneously in a few days, up to 70% of patients with chikungunya develop chronic arthralgia/arthritis that lasts months or years.  Treatment is mainly supportive, but patients with severe, long-lasting joint symptoms sometimes require disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (eg, methotrexate).

(Choice B)  Disseminated gonococcus infection can cause rash and joint symptoms (eg, tenosynovitis, polyarthralgia).  However, the rash is marked by a few scattered pustules or vesicopustules, not a diffuse maculopapular rash.

(Choice C)  Infectious mononucleosis often causes fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and generalized rash.  However, most patients have pharyngitis and atypical lymphocytosis; in addition, polyarticular arthralgia/arthritis would be atypical.

(Choice D)  Reactive arthritis typically causes asymmetric oligoarthritis, conjunctivitis, and oral lesions 1-4 weeks after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract infection.  The presence of symmetric polyarthritis and a lack of conjunctivitis and oral lesions make reactive arthritis less likely.

(Choice E)  Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause constitutional symptoms (eg, fever, myalgias), symmetric arthritis (usually hands), and rash.  However, the rash is typically in sun-exposed areas (eg, malar), not diffuse; in addition, this patient's high fever and symptom onset shortly after traveling make an infectious etiology more likely.

Educational objective:
Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness endemic to tropical and subtropical regions.  It typically presents with high fever, diffuse maculopapular rash, and severe polyarthralgia/arthritis.  Although most initial symptoms resolve spontaneously within days, polyarthralgia/arthritis may persist for months or years.

questionList.title: Chikungunya fever

questionList.questionText: A 3-day-old boy is being evaluated in the newborn nursery due to a failed hearing screening.  The infant was born at 38 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery following a pregnancy complicated by limited prenatal care.  During the delivery, maternal pulmonary edema developed secondary to preeclampsia, and a dose of furosemide was required.  The patient developed physiologic jaundice but did not require phototherapy.  Weight, length, and head circumference are all below the 5th percentile for gestational age.  On examination, the patient is awake and alert.  Red reflexes are present bilaterally.  The lungs are clear to auscultation.  Heart rate and rhythm are normal, with S1 and S2 present without appreciable murmurs, rubs, or gallops.  The abdomen is soft and nondistended, and there is mild hepatosplenomegaly.  Neurologic examination is unremarkable.  Routine hearing screening has failed twice bilaterally, which is suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss.  Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's hearing loss?
questionList.explanationText:
Key features of congenital infections*

Toxoplasmosis

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Diffuse intracranial calcifications

Syphilis

  • Rhinorrhea
  • Skeletal anomalies
  • Desquamating rash (palms/soles)

Rubella

  • Cataracts
  • Heart defects (eg, PDA)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss

Cytomegalovirus

  • Periventricular calcifications
  • Microcephaly
  • Sensorineural hearing loss

Herpes simplex virus

  • Vesicular/ulcerative rash

*Nonspecific findings include growth restriction, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly & blueberry muffin rash.

PDA = patent ductus arteriosus.

This newborn has bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, which can be genetic or caused by brainstem injury (eg, hypoxic-ischemic), ototoxic drugs, or intrauterine infection (eg, cytomegalovirus, rubella).  In this case, the presence of systemic findings (ie, hepatosplenomegaly, growth restriction) makes an infectious etiology most likely.

Congenital (TORCH) infections are due to transplacental transmission of a pathogen from an infected mother to the fetus.  Maternal infection may be asymptomatic or mild/nonspecific (eg, fever, rash, malaise) and go undiagnosed.  Nonspecific findings of congenital infection in the neonate are also common and include jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly due to activation of the reticuloendothelial system.  Intrauterine growth restriction, caused by diffuse fetal inflammation, is classic; proportionally low head circumference, weight, and length (ie, symmetric growth restriction), as in this neonate, are suggestive of early (ie, first trimester) transmission of the pathogen.

Infection-specific findings can sometimes be seen (eg, cataracts and patent ductus arteriosus in congenital rubella syndrome, periventricular calcifications in congenital cytomegalovirus), thereby helping differentiate the pathogen; however, they are not always present, as in this patient (no murmurs, red reflexes present).  The diagnosis is typically made with pathogen-specific serology or PCR.

(Choice A)  Group B Streptococcus (GBS) colonization of the maternal genital tract can lead to neonatal GBS sepsis, causing lethargy, temperature instability, and/or respiratory distress.  Hepatosplenomegaly can occur, but this patient's symmetric growth restriction suggests an insult early in gestation rather than during delivery.  Moreover, hearing loss would not be expected at birth.

(Choice B)  Severe, prolonged, and untreated hyperbilirubinemia can cause ototoxicity.  However, this patient's jaundice has been present for only days and does not warrant phototherapy.  In addition, hyperbilirubinemia would not cause symmetric growth restriction.

(Choice C)  A genetic abnormality (eg, Waardenburg syndrome) is an unlikely cause of hearing loss in a patient with systemic symptoms and no syndromic features.  In addition, congenital auditory canal stenosis causes conductive, not sensorineural, hearing loss.

(Choice D)  Exposure to ototoxic drugs (eg, aminoglycosides, loop diuretics) is a risk factor for hearing loss but does not explain this patient's growth restriction or hepatosplenomegaly.  In addition, this patient was exposed to only a single dose of maternally administered furosemide, which is unlikely to cause ototoxicity in the newborn.

Educational objective:
Congenital infection (eg, rubella, cytomegalovirus) should be suspected in a newborn with sensorineural hearing loss and systemic findings (eg, hepatosplenomegaly, symmetric growth restriction).  Pathogenesis involves transplacental transmission of the pathogen from the mother to the fetus.

questionList.title: Rubella

answerChoiceList.choice: Bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract
Congenital stenosis of the auditory canals

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Congenital rubella.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man comes to the office due to a month of intermittent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain and a 4-kg (9-lb) unintentional weight loss.  The patient has no dizziness or chest pain.  He was diagnosed with HIV a year ago after several years of intravenous heroin use.  The patient does not take antiretroviral treatment consistently and no longer uses recreational drugs.  He is currently engaged to an HIV-negative woman.  The patient has never traveled abroad.  Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min.  The mucous membranes are moist, and moderate cervical lymphadenopathy is present.  Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant.  Laboratory results are normal except for a CD4 count of 28/mm3 and a potassium count of 3.2 mEq/L.  What is the most likely cause of this patient's diarrhea?
questionList.explanationText:
Common causes of diarrhea in patients with AIDS

Organism

CD4 count

Symptoms

Cryptosporidium

<180/mm3

  • Severe watery diarrhea
  • Low-grade fever
  • Weight loss

Microsporidium/Isosporidium

<100/mm3

  • Watery diarrhea
  • Crampy abdominal pain
  • Weight loss
  • Fever is rare

Mycobacterium avium complex

<50/mm3

  • Watery diarrhea
  • High fever (>39 C [102.2 F])
  • Weight loss

Cytomegalovirus

<50/mm3

  • Frequent, small-volume diarrhea
  • Hematochezia
  • Abdominal pain
  • Low-grade fever
  • Weight loss

Patients with advanced AIDS are at high risk for infectious diarrhea due to a variety of opportunistic bacterial, viral, and protozoal pathogens.  Although delineation of the underlying organism typically requires stool and blood evaluation, a specific diagnosis is often suspected based on the quality (eg, watery or bloody, small or large volume) and frequency of the diarrhea.

In this case, the presence of low-grade fever, abdominal pain, intermittent bloody stools, and a CD4 count <50/mm3 raises strong suspicion for cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis.  CMV is a common opportunistic pathogen in patients with untreated AIDS; it is most prone to attack the retina and gastrointestinal system.  CMV colitis generally presents with progressive fatigue, low-grade fever, weight loss, and frequent, low-volume, bloody stools.  As with other causes of diarrhea, hypokalemia may be present but is nonspecific.

Diagnosis is typically made using colonoscopy with biopsy (eosinophilic intranuclear and basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions).  Although most patients with CMV colitis have evidence of CMV viremia, the presence of viremia cannot be used to diagnose end-organ disease (because viremia can occur without end-organ damage).  Treatment with ganciclovir improves symptoms, but patients require antiretroviral therapy to prevent relapse.  All patients with active CMV also require an ocular examination to rule out concurrent retinitis.

(Choice A)  Cryptosporidiosis is a common cause of chronic, profuse, watery diarrhea in patients with AIDS who have CD4 counts <180/mm3.  This pathogen does not typically cause bloody stools.

(Choice C)  Entamoeba histolytica can cause bloody stools and fever but most often is acquired during international travel in countries with poor sanitation.  It is not a common opportunistic pathogen in patients with AIDS in the United States.

(Choice D)  Giardia causes malabsorptive, watery diarrhea.  It can become chronic and result in significant weight loss (10%-20% or more) in patients with AIDS.  However, it does not typically cause bloody stools.

(Choice E)  Herpes simplex is usually associated with painful esophagitis or genital lesions in patients with HIV.  It is an uncommon cause of colitis compared with CMV.

(Choice F)  Kaposi sarcoma (KS) of the gastrointestinal tract can cause hematochezia, but fevers would be less likely.  AIDS-related KS is much more common among men who have sex with men than among other populations with HIV (eg, intravenous drug users).

(Choice G)  Disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection can cause chronic diarrhea and weight loss; however, the diarrhea is typically watery, not bloody.

Educational objective:
Patients with AIDS who have CD4 counts <50/mm3 are at high risk for infectious colitis with opportunistic bacterial, viral, and protozoal pathogens.  Cytomegalovirus colitis should be suspected in those with frequent, small-volume, bloody stools and abdominal pain.  Diagnosis is confirmed by colonoscopy with biopsy.  Any patient with HIV who has active CMV disease requires ocular examination to rule out concurrent retinitis.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Cytomegalovirus

questionList.questionText: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to fever and rash for 6 days and difficulty breathing for the past day.  The rash began on the patient's face and spread to his trunk and extremities.  Prior to the onset of rash, he had a cough, tearing of eyes, a runny nose, and nasal congestion.  The child has had no vaccinations.  Temperature is 39.5 C (103.1 F) and respirations are 44/min.  Physical examination shows a tired-appearing boy with a diffuse, erythematous, maculopapular rash all over the body except the palms and soles.  Auscultation of the chest reveals bilateral crackles.  The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.  The child is admitted to the hospital.  Which of the following reduces morbidity and mortality in the patient's most likely condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Measles virus (rubeola)

Transmission

  • Airborne respiratory particles

Clinical features

  • Prodrome (eg, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, fever, Koplik spots)
  • Maculopapular exanthem
    • Cephalocaudal & centrifugal spread
    • Usually spares palms & soles

Management

  • Supportive care
  • Vitamin A

Complications

  • Pneumonia
  • Neurologic (variable onset)
    • Encephalitis (days)
    • Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (weeks)
    • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (years)

Prevention

  • Live attenuated vaccine

This unvaccinated child has fever and a diffuse maculopapular rash following a prodrome of cough, conjunctivitis, and coryza, findings consistent with measles (rubeola).  The rash characteristically begins on the face and spreads cephalocaudally, often sparing the palms and soles, as in this patient.  In this case, the disease course has been complicated by pneumonia, which is clinically evident given the patient's shortness of breath, tachypnea, and crackles; pneumonia may be due to the measles virus itself or a secondary bacterial infection.

Management of measles is primarily supportive (eg, fluids, antipyretics), and in most patients symptoms resolve within 1-2 weeks.  However, increased morbidity (eg, prolonged illness, hospitalization) and mortality are associated with vitamin A deficiency, particularly in young children.  Because measles can also precipitate vitamin A deficiency (likely due to increased use during the acute illness), vitamin A administration is recommended for children with measles, especially those with severe disease, as in this child who is hospitalized with pneumonia.  Vitamin A likely reduces complications through the promotion of antibody-producing cells and regeneration of epithelial cells (eg, in the gut, lungs, and retina).

(Choice B)  Patients treated for pulmonary tuberculosis may require vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation to reduce the adverse effects of isoniazid (an antitubercular medication), not to reduce morbidity of the infection itself.  Pulmonary tuberculosis may present with fever and cough, but this patient's cephalocaudal maculopapular rash is not a characteristic feature.

(Choice C)  Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) supplementation is typically administered in the setting of malabsorptive disorders that affect the terminal ileum, such as Crohn disease.  This patient has no gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, abdominal pain, bloody stools) to suggest this diagnosis.

(Choices D and E)  Vitamins E and K are fat-soluble vitamins that must be replenished in disorders that cause pancreatic insufficiency (eg, cystic fibrosis).  However, manifestations of pancreatic insufficiency include steatorrhea and bloating, features not seen in this patient.

Educational objective:
Measles presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by a maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalocaudal pattern.  Although treatment is primarily supportive, vitamin A should be administered to children with measles to reduce morbidity and mortality.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Measles

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Measles.

questionList.questionText: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office due to vulvar pain and dysuria that started 2 days ago.  The patient has had no increased urinary frequency or flank pain.  She has never had similar symptoms.  The patient returned from a trip to the Caribbean 2 weeks ago and has had intermittent fever and malaise over the past week.  She is sexually active and has had 3 new male partners over the past 6 months.  She has no chronic medical conditions and takes a combined estrogen/progestin oral contraceptive pill.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination shows grouped, shallow ulcers with surrounding erythema on the left labia minora.  The left inguinal lymph nodes are tender to palpation.  Urinalysis shows 5-10 leukocytes/hpf and 1-2 erythrocytes/hpf.  Urine culture is negative.  Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Infectious genital ulcers

Painful

Herpes simplex virus

  • Pustules, vesicles, or small ulcers on erythematous base
  • Tender lymphadenopathy
  • Systemic symptoms common

Haemophilus ducreyi (chancroid)

  • Larger, deep ulcers with gray/yellow exudate
  • Well-demarcated borders & soft, friable base
  • Severe lymphadenopathy that may suppurate

Painless

Treponema pallidum (syphilis)

  • Usually single ulcer (chancre)
  • Indurated borders & hard, nonpurulent base

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3 (lymphogranuloma venereum)

  • Initial small, shallow ulcers (often missed)
  • Then painful & fluctuant adenitis (buboes)

This patient's grouped, shallow genital ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy are consistent with herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.  Individuals with HSV typically have primary and recurrent infections; those with primary infection often have systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) in addition to genital lesions.

HSV lesions initially appear as a group of painful vesicles on an erythematous base; the vesicles evolve into a group of shallow ulcers that eventually crust over.  Patients can have painful urination due to urine contact on the open ulcers and sterile pyuria (leukocytes on urinalysis but negative urine culture) due to vulvar inflammation.  Some patients with primary disease also develop a viral infection within the lumbosacral plexus that causes autonomic nervous system dysfunction, leading to acute urinary retention.  Primary HSV infections are managed with antiviral therapy (eg, acyclovir, valacyclovir), which can decrease symptom severity and duration.

(Choice A)  Serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum, a genital ulcer disease common in tropical and subtropical areas (eg, Caribbean).  Manifestations begin with a small, painless ulcer that often goes unnoticed.  Several weeks later, patients develop painful, swollen, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).  This patient has concurrent genital ulcers on an erythematous base, systemic symptoms, and regional lymphadenopathy, making HSV far more likely.

(Choice B)  Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, a rare sexually transmitted infection.  Occasional outbreaks occur primarily in Southeast Asia, sub-Saharan Africa, and Latin America.  Patients typically develop ≥1 erythematous papules that turn into pustules and ulcerate; the ulcers are large and deep and tend to have an erythematous base and a gray-yellow exudate.  Suppurative lymphadenopathy is usually present.  Chancroid is not expected to appear as a group of shallow ulcers and is far less common than HSV.

(Choice D)  Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), which is endemic in tropical and subtropical climates (eg, India, Guyana, New Guinea).  Patients have extensive, painless genital ulcers, usually with no associated lymphadenopathy.

(Choice E)  Treponema pallidum causes syphilis.  Patients with primary syphilis typically have a single painless ulcer (ie, chancre) and bilateral, nontender lymphadenopathy.  Those with secondary syphilis may have systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) and are expected to develop raised, flat genital lesions (condyloma lata) rather than ulcerative lesions.

Educational objective:
Primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can present with systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) and a cluster of painful ulcers with associated tender lymphadenopathy.  Some patients have painful urination and a sterile pyuria.  Primary HSV is managed with antiviral medication (eg, acyclovir, valacyclovir), which decreases symptom severity and duration.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: HSV infection

Current concepts for genital herpes simplex virus infection: diagnostics and pathogenesis of genital tract shedding.
Diagnosis and management of genital ulcers.

questionList.questionText:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the office due to a flulike illness with low-grade fever, malaise, nausea, and anorexia.  She came back from a trip to Honduras a week ago, and her symptoms started 2 days prior to her return.  The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications.  She occasionally smokes marijuana and has used injection drugs in the past.  She has had several sexual partners and currently lives with her boyfriend.  Temperature is 37.9 C (100.2 F), blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min.  The patient has scleral icterus.  Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable.  The liver edge, palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin, is smooth and tender.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Total bilirubin44.8 mg/dL
Aspartate aminotransferase11,222 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase21,184 U/L
Hepatitis panel
    Hepatitis B surface antibodypositive
    Hepatitis B core antibodypositive
    Hepatitis B surface antigennegative
    Hepatitis A IgM antibodypositive
    Hepatitis A IgG antibodynegative
    Hepatitis C antibodynegative

After discussing the findings, the patient says she is worried that she may transmit the disease to her boyfriend.  Which of the following interventions for the boyfriend is most likely to decrease his risk of disease acquisition?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with both acute hepatitis A virus infection (markedly elevated transaminases, positive hepatitis A IgM antibody [Ab], negative hepatitis A IgG Ab, recent travel to Honduras) and prior hepatitis B virus infection (positive hepatitis B core Ab, positive hepatitis B surface Ab, history of intravenous drug use).  Since the introduction of routine hepatitis A vaccination in the United States, infection rates have fallen significantly, but disease transmission remains a risk for a number of groups, including international travelers, men who have sex with men, illicit drug users, and those with household or sexual contact with infected persons.  Transmission occurs most frequently via the fecal-oral route, although sexual and blood-borne transmission can also occur.

Postexposure prophylaxis with hepatitis A vaccine or hepatitis A immune globulin should be considered in a number of groups, including:

  • Close personal contacts (eg, sexual contacts, household contacts) of hepatitis A-infected patients
  • Child care center contacts (eg, staff and children) where staff, children, or household contacts of attendees have been infected
  • Food preparation workers whose coworkers have been infected

Prophylaxis should be given within 2 weeks of exposure; in general, younger patients (age <40) should receive hepatitis A vaccine, whereas older patients (age >41) should receive hepatitis A immune globulin.

(Choice A)  Although sexual transmission of hepatitis A virus may occur occasionally, barrier contraceptive use alone would not provide adequate protection against the most common route of transmission (fecal-oral).

(Choices C, D, and E)  This patient's viral markers imply previous hepatitis B infection (core Ab) with resolution (surface Ab), making further vaccination and treatment for hepatitis B unnecessary.  Postexposure prophylaxis with hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine would be administered to a patient with a percutaneous or sexual exposure to an individual with positive hepatitis B surface antigen.

Educational objective:
Postexposure prophylaxis with either hepatitis A vaccine or hepatitis A immune globulin should be considered in a number of groups, including those with close personal contact (eg, sexual contacts, household contacts) with infected patients.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hepatitis a

answerChoiceList.choice: Hepatitis B vaccine and immune globulin

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Hepatitis A.

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 26 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: fever and lethargy
History of Present Illness:
• returned from southeast Asia 10 days ago after staying 2 weeks to visit his family
• 3 days after his return, developed fever, headache, and severe joint and muscle pain
• did not receive pretravel vaccinations or prophylaxis while traveling
Past Medical History:
• none
Medications:
• none
Allergies:
• no known drug allergies
Family History:
• noncontributory
Psychosocial History:
• graduate student
• does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
39.1 C
(102.4 F)		110/min19/min80/50
mm Hg		96%
on RA		–––

• Appearance: ill-appearing; tachypneic
• Skin: pale and clammy; diffuse maculopapular rash over trunk and extremities; scattered petechiae
• Pulmonary: diffuse crackles; diminished breath sounds at bilateral bases
• Cardiac: regular rhythm; tachycardia; S1 and S2
• Abdominal: soft, nontender; significant hepatomegaly >4 cm below the right costal margin
• Neurologic: speech slurred; difficult to arouse for questions

Diagnostic Studies

Complete blood count
Hematocrit53%
Platelets15,000/mm3
Leukocytes2,000/mm3
Reticulocytes1.2%
Liver function studies
Albumin2.5 g/dL
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)1,006 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)1,114 U/L
Coagulation studies
PT13 sec
Activated PTT42 sec

Question: Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
Manifestations of dengue infection

Nonhemorrhagic

  • Flu-like febrile illness
  • Marked myalgia &/or arthralgia
  • Diffuse maculopapular rash
  • Retroorbital pain
  • Leukopenia

Hemorrhagic

  • Increased vascular permeability
  • Positive tourniquet test*
  • Hemoconcentration & thrombocytopenia
  • Spontaneous bleeding → shock

*Petechiae after sphygmomanometer cuff inflation for 5 min.

This patient traveled to southeast Asia and now has a severe febrile illness.  Although a wide range of pathogens can infect travelers who do not receive pretravel vaccinations or prophylaxis, this patient's high fever, diffuse maculopapular rash, severe myalgia/arthralgia, hemorrhagic manifestations, and signs of shock (eg, hypotension, altered mental state) indicate dengue infection.

Dengue is a viral infection transmitted by female Aedes mosquitoes.  Approximately 400 million cases occur annually, and prevalence is particularly high in tropical/subtropical regions of Asia and South America.  Manifestations of infection typically begin 4-7 days after transmission with acute-onset high fever, retroorbital headache, and severe myalgia/arthralgia ("breakbone fever").  Hemorrhagic symptoms (eg, mucosal bleeding, petechiae) are common, and hepatomegaly can develop.  Laboratory evaluation usually reveals leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and hemoconcentration (eg, elevated hematocrit due to capillary leakage).

The most severe form of illness, dengue shock syndrome, usually arises in patients with repeat infection with a different serotype.  Manifestations typically occur as the patient begins to defervesce on the third to fifth day of illness.  Dengue shock syndrome is marked by severe capillary leakage leading to circulatory collapse and end-organ damage (eg, impaired consciousness, severe transaminase elevation).  Urgent resuscitation is required to prevent death.

(Choice B)  Travelers to developing nations are at high risk for hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection due to ingestion of contaminated food/water.  Although HAV infection frequently causes fever, general malaise, transaminase elevation, and hepatomegaly, most cases are marked by jaundice and impaired liver synthetic function (eg, increased PT/PTT).  Circulatory collapse is unlikely in the absence of fulminant liver failure.

(Choice C)  Malaria is endemic in parts of southeast Asia and frequently infects travelers who do not take prophylactic medications.  Although systemic symptoms, high fever, and transaminase elevation are common, patients almost always have anemia due to lysis of erythrocytes by parasites.

(Choice D)  Parvovirus B19 causes an infection associated with rash and arthralgia, but severe presentations (eg, aplastic crisis) are rare and usually occur in patients with underlying hematologic disorders.

(Choice E)  Typhoid fever frequently causes febrile illness in travelers and is associated with a stepwise illness marked by prominent gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, diarrhea, abdominal pain), cutaneous rose spots, and risk of intestinal perforation.

Educational objective:
Dengue is a virus spread by female Aedes mosquitoes.  It is endemic in many tropical and subtropical areas, particularly in Asia and South America.  Illness usually presents with high fever, diffuse rash, severe myalgia/arthralgia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia.  Repeat infection often leads to a life-threatening shock syndrome.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Dengue fever

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Dengue.

questionList.questionText:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to 3 days of fever, malaise, progressive dyspnea on exertion, dry cough, abdominal pain, and watery diarrhea.  Her loose stools this morning were accompanied by bright red blood.  The patient underwent allogeneic renal transplantation 6 months ago and is currently taking tacrolimus, mycophenolate, and prednisone.  Two months ago, she developed severe leukopenia, which resolved after discontinuing trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and valganciclovir.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 114/min, and respirations are 22/min.  Physical examination shows bilateral lung crackles and diffuse abdominal tenderness.  Gross blood is seen on rectal examination.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hematocrit30%
    Platelets118,000/mm3
    Leukocytes3,800/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Blood urea nitrogen24 mg/dL
    Creatinine1.2 mg/dL
Liver function studies
    Total bilirubin1.3 mg/dL
    Alkaline phosphatase124 U/L
    Aspartate aminotransferase137 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase114 U/L

Urinalysis is normal.  Chest x-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Patients receiving solid organ transplantations require high-dose immunosuppressive medication to prevent organ rejection.  This results in systemic immunosuppression, which puts them at risk for opportunistic infections, most notably Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) and cytomegalovirus (CMV).

This patient was on prophylaxis for PCP (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) and CMV (valganciclovir), but both medications were discontinued 2 months ago due to leukopenia.  She now presents with pulmonary symptoms (dyspnea on exertion, dry cough), gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, diarrhea, hematochezia), pancytopenia, mild hepatitis, and interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray.  This combination of findings strongly suggests tissue-invasive CMV disease (causing pneumonitis, gastroenteritis, and hepatitis).  Viremia can be detected in the blood using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) but may not always be present; tissue biopsy is the gold standard.  Treatment involves discontinuing antimetabolite immunosuppression (eg, mycophenolate) and initiating antiviral therapy.  Intravenous ganciclovir is used for patients with severe disease (eg, pneumonitis, meningoencephalitis, high viral loads, significant gastrointestinal disease).  Patients with minimal signs and symptoms can take oral valganciclovir.

(Choice A)  Aspergillosis primarily causes pulmonary disease (fever, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis), although it may involve other organs.  Aspergillosis tends to cause nodules and focal infiltrates on chest x-ray (not bilateral interstitial infiltrates), and gastrointestinal disease is uncommon.

(Choice B)  Candida colonizes airways and usually does not cause pneumonia.  Gastrointestinal disease is also uncommon.

(Choice C)  Cryptosporidium causes diarrhea in immunosuppressed patients but usually does not involve the lung.

(Choice E)  Influenza typically causes high fever, headache, malaise, and sore throat.  Pneumonia is a common complication.  Gastrointestinal disease (colitis), pancytopenia, and hepatitis are uncommon.

(Choice F)  Legionella often presents with high fever (>39 C [102.2 F]), gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, diarrhea), and pulmonary symptoms.  However, bloody diarrhea is an unusual manifestation of legionellosis and CMV is a far more prevalent infection.  If the CMV DNA PCR is negative, other less common causes (eg, Legionella) can be explored.

(Choice G)  Mycoplasma causes headache, fever, sore throat, and cough.  It typically does not cause gastrointestinal symptoms.

(Choice H)  Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is a common infection in solid organ transplant patients who do not receive prophylaxis.  PCP presents with pulmonary symptoms (respiratory failure, cough, dyspnea) but typically does not cause gastrointestinal or hepatic issues.

Educational objective:
Patients who receive a solid organ transplant are at risk for opportunistic infections, most notably Pneumocystis pneumonia and cytomegalovirus (CMV).  In the absence of prophylaxis, patients who present with a systemic illness involving multiple organ systems (eg, pneumonitis, hepatitis, gastroenteritis) should be tested for CMV.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Cytomegalovirus

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old boy is seen in the clinic due to recent exposure to chickenpox.  He was in class with another child who had a rash that was diagnosed as chickenpox.  His last exposure to the child was 7 days ago.  The patient has had no fever, sore throat, or rash.  He has no medical conditions and has not had chickenpox in the past.  The patient has received no vaccinations due to parental preference.  Vital signs are normal.  Examination shows no rash and is otherwise unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Chickenpox is a highly contagious infection caused by varicella-zoster virus (VZV).  Transmission is via contact with skin lesions or aerosolized respiratory secretions.

Although <5% of fully vaccinated individuals develop active infection after exposure, nonimmune patients (ie, no prior infection or <2 vaccine doses) are at much higher risk for infection, with transmission rates >90% in fully unvaccinated patients following close contact with a VZV-infected patient.  However, this rate is dramatically reduced with postexposure prophylaxis (PEP).

In those who are immunocompetent and varicella nonimmune, management depends on the time since last varicella exposure:

  • ≤5 days after exposure:  Patients age ≥1 should receive the VZV vaccine as PEP (Choice A).  Children age <1 (outside of the immediate newborn period) cannot receive the VZV vaccine and are low risk for severe infection, and therefore do not require PEP.

  • >5 days after exposure (as in this case):  Due to lack of effectiveness after this time interval, PEP is not indicated and management is observation for rash, which can occur up to 21 days after exposure.  However, to prevent future infection unrelated to the recent exposure, the VZV vaccine is still universally recommended in nonimmune children age ≥1.

(Choices B and E)  The live VZV vaccine is contraindicated in those who are immunocompromised, pregnant, or in the immediate newborn period (eg, neonates born to a mother with VZV infection).  Due to high risk for severe infection, PEP in these groups is with varicella-zoster immune globulin (VariZIG) within 10 days of exposure.  Prophylactic acyclovir can be given as an adjunct to VariZIG in some patients who are immunocompromised, but its use alone is generally not preferred (due to limited proven efficacy) unless VariZIG is unavailable.

(Choice C)  Varicella titers are not recommended prior to administration of PEP and would be negative in this child with no history of chickenpox or varicella vaccination.  In addition, VariZIG is reserved for patients with contraindications to the VZV vaccine (eg, immunocompromised), not present in this case.

Educational objective:
Chickenpox postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in nonimmune, immunocompetent patients includes varicella vaccine ≤5 days after exposure.  PEP is not indicated in healthy children presenting >5 days after exposure, but the varicella vaccine is recommended to prevent future infection.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Chicken pox

answerChoiceList.choice: Administer varicella vaccination now as postexposure prophylaxis
Administer varicella-zoster immune globulin now as postexposure prophylaxis
Measure varicella IgG and administer varicella-zoster immune globulin prophylaxis if low
No postexposure prophylaxis indicated but recommend varicella vaccination
Start oral acyclovir now as postexposure prophylaxis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Varicella-zoster virus post-exposure management and prophylaxis: a review.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with 3 days of burning substernal chest pain and "excruciating" pain with swallowing.  She could not eat or drink anything today due to severe pain.  She has not had nausea, vomiting, difficulty initiating swallowing, or a sensation of food getting stuck in her throat.  The patient has a history of HIV, asthma, and uterine fibroids.  Her current medications include atazanavir-ritonavir, tenofovir, emtricitabine, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, azithromycin, and albuterol.  She has a history of medication noncompliance but says that she is currently taking all her medications as prescribed.  Her most recent CD4 count was 30/mm3.  Her temperature is 37.9 C (100.2 F), blood pressure is 108/59 mm Hg, and pulse is 103/min.  The patient is thin and somewhat pale.  She has significant dental caries, but oral examination is otherwise normal.  Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Empiric therapy is initiated, and upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is scheduled.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Common causes of esophagitis in patients with HIV

Candida albicans

  • Oral thrush usually present
  • White plaques throughout esophagus
  • Biopsy: pseudohyphae

Herpes simplex virus

  • Orolabial lesions usually present
  • Vesicular or ulcerative round/ovoid lesions (volcano-like)
  • Biopsy: multinucleated giant cells

Cytomegalovirus

  • Large, linear ulcers in distal esophagus
  • Biopsy: intranuclear/intracytoplasmic inclusions

Infectious esophagitis is common in patients with advanced HIV, especially with CD4 counts <100/mm3.  The most common cause of esophagitis in patients with HIV is Candida albicans (>60% of cases); however, viral esophagitis is more likely than candidal esophagitis in patients (such as this one) who have:

  • Severe odynophagia (pain with swallowing) as the predominant symptom

  • No dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)

  • No thrush

The most commonly implicated viruses in viral esophagitis include herpes simplex virus (HSV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV).  The diagnosis is generally made on upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy.  HSV usually causes circular or ovoid vesicular and ulcerated lesions.  CMV infection typically causes large, linear distal esophageal ulcers.  Histopathology and culture confirm the diagnosis.

(Choice A)  Several features make viral esophagitis more likely than Candida esophagitis in this patient:  The large majority of patients with Candida esophagitis have oral thrush (although lack of thrush does not exclude the diagnosis); most have prominent dysphagia rather than odynophagia; and, if present, odynophagia is generally mild to moderate (rather than severe, as in this patient).  Symptomatic patients (especially with visible thrush) can be treated empirically for Candida esophagitis with fluconazole; endoscopy is usually performed in those failing treatment.

(Choice B)  Eosinophilic esophagitis can be seen in patients who have atopic conditions (eg, asthma, seasonal allergies).  However, it is an uncommon disorder, and manifestations typically include dysphagia, heartburn, and refractory acid reflux; odynophagia (especially severe) is rare.  In addition, symptoms usually develop chronically (months to years) rather than acutely as seen in this patient.

(Choice C)  Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) typically presents with heartburn, chest pain, and dysphagia.  However, odynophagia (especially severe) is not commonly associated with GERD and warrants evaluation for other possible causes.

(Choice D)  Medication-related chemical esophagitis ("pill esophagitis") can cause acute odynophagia due to direct effects of a medication on esophageal mucosa.  Common offending medications include potassium chloride, tetracyclines, bisphosphonates, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  Although other large or multi-pill medications can cause dysphagia, they less commonly cause true pill esophagitis.

Educational objective:
Infectious esophagitis is a common complication seen in patients with advanced HIV disease.  Patients with oral thrush most likely have Candida esophagitis, with viral causes (eg, herpes simplex, cytomegalovirus) being more likely in the setting of severe odynophagia without dysphagia or thrush.  The diagnosis is confirmed with upper gastrointestinal endoscopy.

questionList.title: Esophagitis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Diagnosis and management of infectious esophagitis associated with human immunodeficiency virus infection.

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to 3 days of fever.  For the past 2 days he has also had throat pain and has not eaten well.  His father is worried because the boy is due to start the fall school term in 2 weeks.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions and is current with his immunizations.  He lives with his older brother, parents, and grandmother.  Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 108/58 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, and respirations are 18/min.  The oropharynx has several scattered, 1-mm vesicles on the anterior palatine pillars.  Several gray, shallow ulcers are also seen on the soft palate and uvula, but the tongue, lips, and buccal mucosa are spared.  The skin has no rashes.  The remainder of the physical examination is normal.  Which of the following is the most likely pathogen associated with this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Herpangina vs herpetic gingivostomatitis

Herpangina

Herpetic gingivostomatitis

Etiology

  • Coxsackievirus A
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1

Patient age

  • 3-10 years
  • 6 months to 5 years

Seasonality

  • Late summer/early fall
  • None

Clinical features

  • Fever & pharyngitis
  • Gray vesicles/ulcers on posterior oropharynx
  • Fever & pharyngitis
  • Clusters of vesicles/ulcers on anterior oral mucosa & lips
  • Erythematous & edematous gingiva

Treatment

  • Supportive
  • Oral acyclovir

Herpangina and herpetic gingivostomatitis are common vesicular oral infections in children.  They present similarly with fever and pharyngitis; however, the primary distinguishing feature is the location of the oral lesions.

Herpangina is caused by Coxsackie virus and typically affects young children in the late summer or early fall.  Patients have gray vesicles that progress to fibrin-coated ulcers.  The oral enanthem is located in the oropharynx on the posterior soft palate, anterior palatine pillars, tonsils, and uvula.  Unlike hand-foot-and-mouth disease, another condition caused by Coxsackie virus, herpangina is not associated with a rash.

In contrast, herpetic gingivostomatitis is a herpes simplex virus infection characterized by clusters of vesicles that generally localize to the anterior oral cavity (buccal mucosa, tongue, gingiva, hard palate) and lips (Choice D).

This patient with ulcers in the back of the mouth has herpangina.  Treatment is supportive (eg, oral hydration, analgesia) as lesions self-resolve within a week.

(Choice A)  Adenovirus is a common cause of tonsillitis in children and presents with fever, cough, and sore throat.  Tonsillar exudates may be present, but not oropharyngeal vesicles or ulcers.

(Choice C)  Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the primary cause of infectious mononucleosis.  It typically presents with fever, pharyngitis, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudates.  EBV does not cause oral vesicles or ulcers.

(Choice E)  Streptococcus pyogenes is the primary cause of streptococcal pharyngitis, which presents with fever, sore throat, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudates.  The absence of exudates and presence of vesicles in this patient make the diagnosis of Streptococcus less likely.

Educational objective:
Herpangina is caused by Coxsackie virus infection.  It typically presents with fever and oropharyngeal vesicles and ulcers on the posterior soft palate, palatine pillars, tonsils, and uvula.

questionList.title: Herpangina

questionList.questionText:
A 22-year-old man comes to the urgent care clinic due to 2 weeks of fever, sore throat, and malaise.  He has tried several over-the-counter products with minimal relief.  The patient recently returned from a trip to Honduras for volunteer work.  Temperature is 38.8 C (101.8 F), blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Mild jaundice is present.  The tonsils are enlarged, erythematous, and covered with white exudates.  Enlarged lymph nodes are palpable posterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle bilaterally and in the axillary region.  Breath sounds are normal.  A grade 1/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left infraclavicular region.  The abdomen is soft and nontender with normoactive bowel sounds; mild splenomegaly is present.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin9.4 g/dL
    Mean corpuscular volume90 µm3
    Reticulocytes6%
    Platelets120,000/mm3
    Leukocytes18,000/mm3
Liver function studies
    Total bilirubin5.3 mg/dL
    Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)112 U/L
    Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)99 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Infectious mononucleosis

Clinical features

  • Fever
  • Tonsillitis/pharyngitis ± exudates
  • Posterior or diffuse cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Significant fatigue
  • ± Hepatosplenomegaly
  • ± Rash after amoxicillin

Complications

  • Acute airway obstruction
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia & thrombocytopenia
  • Splenic rupture

Infectious mononucleosis, most commonly due to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, presents with prolonged fever, malaise, and sore throat.  Physical findings include enlarged, erythematous tonsils with exudates; splenomegaly; and lymphadenopathy (commonly posterior cervical but may be generalized).  Laboratory findings can include reactive leukocytosis, positive serum heterophile antibodies (Monospot test), and atypical lymphocytes on blood smear.  Elevated transaminases are also seen in most patients due to mild, transient hepatitis.

In addition, some patients develop autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, rare complications of infectious mononucleosis due to cross-reactivity of EBV-induced antibodies against red blood cells and platelets.  In particular, IgM cold agglutinin antibodies cause complement-mediated destruction of red blood cells.  This hemolysis, which can occur 2-3 weeks after the onset of EBV symptoms, may lead to jaundice, elevated bilirubin, and increased reticulocyte count, as seen in this patient.

(Choice A)  Acute hepatitis A infection can present with fever, malaise, jaundice, and hepatomegaly, particularly in patients who have recently traveled to developing countries.  However, exudative tonsillitis, splenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy are not typical features, and transaminase levels are usually much higher (often >1,000 U/L).

(Choice B)  Acute lymphoblastic leukemia can cause fever, malaise, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy; however, bone marrow failure would cause a low, rather than an elevated, reticulocyte count, as in this patient.  In addition, exudative pharyngitis does not occur.

(Choice C)  Bacterial endocarditis can present with prolonged fever, fatigue, and a cardiac murmur.  However, this patient's soft systolic murmur is not typical of a pathologic murmur and is instead likely due to anemia (turbulent flow due to low blood viscosity).  In addition, pharyngitis is not typically seen with endocarditis, and thrombocytopenia and liver function test abnormalities (including hyperbilirubinemia) are less likely.

(Choice E)  Plasmodium vivax causes malaria, which may present with fever, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia in a patient who has recently traveled to a tropical country.  However, malaria causes cyclic fevers, and exudative pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy are not seen.

Educational objective:
Infectious mononucleosis typically presents with prolonged fever, malaise, exudative pharyngitis, splenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy.  Patients may develop autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia up to 2-3 weeks after the onset of initial symptoms.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Infectious mononucleosis

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents after exposure to a child with a rash.  Two days ago, the patient had a day-long playdate with a friend who had low-grade fever and a vesicular rash.  That friend and another child in the neighborhood were subsequently diagnosed with chickenpox.  The patient has no symptoms and no significant medical history.  He has received only 1 dose of the varicella vaccine at age 1.  He lives at home with his mother, father, and 1-year-old brother.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Examination of the skin, ears, and mucous membranes is normal; the remainder of the examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This child has been exposed to varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which is spread via contact with vesicular fluid or inhalation of airborne infectious respiratory particles.

VZV is extremely contagious, and up to 90% of susceptible (ie, nonimmune) individuals develop chickenpox after exposure to an infected person.  Varicella nonimmunity is defined by an incomplete immunization history (<2 doses of varicella vaccine) and no history of chickenpox.

Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is indicated in nonimmune patients as follows:

  • In immunocompetent children age ≥1, as in this case, PEP is the live varicella vaccine.  The vaccine is ideally given to the exposed individual within 5 days of exposure to help prevent or reduce the severity of infection.  Although the vaccine is not effective as PEP >5 days after exposure, it should still be recommended to prevent future infection.

  • In immunocompromised individuals, live virus vaccines are contraindicated due to the risk of disseminated infection.  Instead, PEP is varicella-zoster immune globulin (VariZIG) (Choice B).  Pregnant women and neonates born to mothers with active infection also require immunoprophylaxis with VariZIG.  Outside of the immediate newborn period, infants age <1 (who cannot receive the live varicella vaccine) do not require VariZIG because they are at relatively low risk for severe disease.

(Choice A)  Prophylactic acyclovir can be given as an adjunct to VariZIG in some patients who are immunocompromised, but its use alone is generally not preferred (due to limited proven efficacy) unless VariZIG is unavailable.  In addition, acyclovir is used to treat active VZV infection (eg, fever, vesicular rash) in high-risk patients (eg, adolescents/adults, immunocompromised individuals).  Antiviral therapy is not indicated in this healthy, asymptomatic child.

(Choice D)  Reassurance and observation are appropriate for an immune child (ie, history of chickenpox or received the 2-dose VZV vaccine series) who has been exposed to varicella.  This patient has received only 1 dose of the vaccine and therefore needs PEP.

Educational objective:
All susceptible (ie, nonimmune), asymptomatic, healthy patients age ≥1 with varicella exposure should receive postexposure prophylaxis with the varicella vaccine within 5 days of exposure.  At-risk patients who cannot receive the varicella vaccine (eg, immunocompromised, pregnant) should receive varicella-zoster immune globulin instead.

questionList.title: Herpes zoster

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Varicella-zoster virus post-exposure management and prophylaxis: a review.

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to vomiting and abdominal pain.  Since this morning, the patient has had multiple episodes of nonbilious, nonbloody emesis as well as intermittent nausea and abdominal pain.  She has also had 3 episodes of watery diarrhea.  The patient attended a school cookout approximately 36 hours prior to her first bout of emesis, and several of her friends who also attended have similar symptoms.  Temperature is 37.4 C (99.1 F), blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg, and pulse is 95/min.  She appears uncomfortable but is alert and interactive.  Mucous membranes are slightly dry.  There is diffuse tenderness to deep palpation on abdominal examination but no masses or hepatosplenomegaly.  The skin is well perfused, and no rashes are evident.  Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's illness?
questionList.explanationText:
Viral gastroenteritis

Epidemiology

  • Fecal-oral transmission
  • Norovirus: most common among all ages
  • Rotavirus: common in unvaccinated age ≤2

Clinical features

  • Emesis &/or watery diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • ± Fever

Diagnosis

  • Clinical*

Treatment

  • Fluid repletion
    • Oral for mild dehydration (eg, normal vital signs, dry mucous membranes)
    • Intravenous for severe dehydration (eg, weak/rapid pulse, marked oliguria, ↑ capillary refill time)
  • Regular diet (with limited fats & simple sugars) as tolerated

*Consider bacterial/parasitic pathogens for the following: grossly bloody stools, persistent fever & exposures (eg, international travel, farm animals).

Norovirus is the most common cause of gastroenteritis in the United States.  Very few viral particles are necessary for infection to spread via fecal-oral route, leading to outbreaks (eg, schools, cruise ships, day care facilities).  Although person-to-person transmission is most common, norovirus infection can also occur with ingestion of contaminated food, such as shellfish, salad, and fruit.

Symptoms typically begin 1-2 days after viral exposure and include nonbloody, nonbilious emesis; watery diarrhea; and abdominal pain.  Diarrhea is noninflammatory without blood or mucus in the stool.  Fever, headache, and malaise are common.

The diagnosis is generally clinical.  However, confirmatory testing (ie, detection of norovirus in the stool) may be performed in outbreaks or atypical cases (eg, symptoms >7 days).  Fecal leukocytes are not seen.

Treatment is supportive with oral or intravenous rehydration therapy depending on severity, and symptom resolution is usually within 2-3 days.  Because norovirus is not killed by alcohol-based sanitizer or standard cleaning solutions, prevention includes diligent hand hygiene using soap and water and cleansing of contaminated surfaces with bleach.

(Choices A and E)  Bacillus cereus and Staphylococcus aureus cause foodborne gastrointestinal illness via ingestion of preformed toxin.  Vomiting is the predominant symptom and typically begins within 6 hours of eating the contaminated food.  In contrast, this patient developed symptoms 36 hours after the cookout.

(Choice C)  Rotavirus causes severe vomiting and watery diarrhea in unvaccinated children age ≤2.  Infection in adolescents and adults is typically mild or asymptomatic due to the presence of antibodies from prior exposure or vaccination.  Rotavirus is less likely than norovirus in this symptomatic, teenage patient.

(Choice D)  Shigella sonnei presents with abrupt onset of high fever, abdominal cramping, and stools containing mucus and/or blood.  This patient is afebrile with watery diarrhea, making norovirus more likely.

Educational objective:
Norovirus is the most common gastroenteritis in the United States and is often implicated in outbreaks on cruise ships and in schools.  Patients develop vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal pain 1-2 days after exposure.  Treatment is supportive, and symptoms generally resolve within 2-3 days.

questionList.questionText:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of malaise, decreased appetite, abdominal discomfort, and bloody stools.  The patient had end-stage renal disease and underwent kidney transplantation 4 months ago.  He had no major postoperative issues and currently takes mycophenolate, tacrolimus, and prednisone.  The patient has a 15 pack-year smoking history but quit several years ago.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 22/min.  Physical examination shows mild abdominal tenderness in the left lower quadrant.  Rectal examination is normal.  Stool is guaiac positive.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin8.1 g/dL
    Platelets190,000/mm3
    Leukocytes3,800/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Creatinine1.2 mg/dL

Atypical lymphocytes are seen on peripheral blood smear.  A colonoscopy reveals multiple ulcerations throughout the colon.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Patients who undergo renal transplantation receive high-dose immunosuppressant medication for several months after surgery, putting them at risk for opportunistic infections.  One of the most common opportunistic infections following renal transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).  CMV is a widely prevalent herpesvirus that establishes a latent infection after initial inoculation.  Most patients remain asymptomatic, but infection may reemerge in patients who are severely immunocompromised.

CMV reactivation results in viremia and/or tissue-invasive disease.  The gastrointestinal tract is the most common organ system affected, and patients usually manifest symptoms of colitis or enteritis, including fever, malaise, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, and abdominal pain.  Laboratory studies often show cytopenias due to bone marrow involvement, and peripheral blood smear typically reveals atypical lymphocytes.

Viremia can be present, but end-organ disease can occur in the absence of viremia; biopsy of the affected organ is the gold standard for diagnosis of tissue-invasive disease.  Patients with symptoms of CMV colitis typically have multiple, large, shallow erosions or ulcers on colonoscopy.  Treatment with antivirals (eg, ganciclovir) and a reduction of immunosuppressant medication is usually required.

(Choice B)  Initial infections with both Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and CMV may cause infectious mononucleosis, and both viruses establish latent infections; however, EBV reactivation is typically associated with malignancies (eg, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma), not colitis.

(Choice C)  Although graft rejection can occur after kidney transplantation, graft-versus-host disease is quite rare.  Graft-versus-host disease is typically seen in patients who have undergone allogeneic stem-cell transplantation.

(Choice D)  Patients who have undergone transplantation are at risk for herpes simplex reactivation with resultant tracheobronchitis, esophagitis, pneumonia, and/or hepatitis; colitis is uncommon.  This patient is much more likely to have CMV reactivation.

(Choice E)  Ischemic colitis can cause abdominal pain and bloody stools; however, atypical lymphocytes are not a feature of this disease and endoscopy usually reveals pale mucosa with petechial bleeding, hemorrhagic nodules, or cyanotic mucosa with hemorrhagic ulcers.

Educational objectives:
Patients who undergo renal transplantations are at risk for cytomegalovirus reactivation with viremia and/or end-organ disease.  Gastrointestinal manifestations are common and include abdominal pain, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, and endoscopic evidence of multiple, large, shallow ulcers.  Biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis of tissue-invasive disease.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Cytomegalovirus

questionMappingReferencesList.title: TORCH infections

questionList.questionText:
A 44-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of a skin lesion.  The patient first noticed the lesion 8 weeks ago, and it appeared flat at onset.  There is no pain or itching, but its color has changed from pink to violet.  He also reports an unintentional weight loss of approximately 8 kg (17.5 lb) over the past year.  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Examination shows anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy.  The lesion is shown in the image below:

What is the best next step to help diagnose this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Kaposi sarcoma

Etiology

  • Endothelial tumor caused by human herpesvirus 8
  • Most common malignancy in patients with untreated HIV
  • Endemic in certain African & Mediterranean regions

Manifestations

  • Cutaneous lesions:
    • Violaceous, red, or brown flat lesions grow into papules
    • Most common along skin folds
    • Pruritus, pain & friability are rare
    • Lymphedema distal to lesions
  • Visceral lesions:
    • Lungs & gastrointestinal tract most common
    • May cause life-threatening bleeding

Treatment

  • HIV-associated KS:
    • Antiretroviral therapy initiation
    • Local or systemic chemotherapy rarely required
  • Endemic KS:
    • Surgery & local therapy are primary modalities

KS = Kaposi sarcoma.

This patient has an elliptical violaceous lesion in the setting of unintentional weight loss and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy.  This presentation raises concern for Kaposi sarcoma (KS) in the setting of undiagnosed HIV infection.  KS is an endothelial tumor caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8).  It is the most common malignancy in patients with untreated HIV and is considered an AIDS-defining illness because most cases arise when immunosuppression becomes severe (eg, CD4 <200/mm3).

KS usually presents as a flat, discolored area that resembles a bruise that does not heal.  Over time, the lesions evolve into papules that are not painful or pruritic.  The color is usually violaceous, red, brown, or yellow due to the large number of erythrocytes passing through the irregular tumor vessels and extravasating heme into surrounding tissue.  Lymphedema may develop distal to the lesions, and visceral lesions in the lungs and gastrointestinal tract can be life-threatening.

The diagnosis of KS is usually made clinically.  All patients with suspected KS should be tested for HIV, particularly when other symptoms (eg, unintentional weight loss, generalized lymphadenopathy) of HIV infection are present.  First-line therapy for HIV-associated KS is the initiation of antiretroviral therapy, which restores the immune response against HHV8 and usually leads to spontaneous remission.

(Choice A)  Blood culture in specialized media can identify Bartonella, which causes bacillary angiomatosis.  Although bacillary angiomatosis lesions are highly vascular, they typically begin as small, red/purple papules that grow into friable, pedunculated lesions.  Furthermore, fever and other systemic symptoms are often present.

(Choice B)  HHV8 is phylogenetically similar to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV); both are oncogenic viruses that establish latent infection in lymphoid cells.  However, EBV primarily causes non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  A purple cutaneous lesion is more consistent with KS.

(Choice D)  Lymph node biopsy is invasive and is generally reserved for unexplained lymphadenopathy.  This patient should first be evaluated for HIV, which is a common cause of lymphadenopathy.  Lymph node biopsy is not indicated at this time.

(Choice E)  Secondary syphilis can cause diffuse mucocutaneous lesions associated with systemic symptoms beginning 1-3 months after the initial infection.  Tertiary gummatous syphilis can occur years after the initial infection and is characterized by nodular or ulcerating lesions with necrosis and scarring.  This patient with a single purple lesion is unlikely to have syphilis.

Educational objective:
Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is the most common cancer in patients with untreated HIV.  All individuals with suspected KS should undergo HIV testing, particularly when other symptoms (eg, unintentional weight loss, lymphadenopathy) of HIV infection are present.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old man comes to the office to "check up on my liver."  He was seen about 2 years ago due to fatigue, anorexia, and jaundice, which developed after sharing needles with another injection drug user.  Viral hepatitis serology testing at that time was positive for hepatitis B surface antigen but negative for all other antigens and antibodies, including hepatitis C.  The patient has not sought medical care since then and has been asymptomatic.  He stopped using injection drugs and is now sober.  He does not use tobacco or alcohol and is in a monogamous relationship with his girlfriend.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  This patient's hepatitis B virus serology testing is most likely to show which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
The response to acute hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection depends heavily on when in life a patient becomes infected:

  • Patients infected during the perinatal period almost universally progress to chronic HBV infection.
  • Children age 1-5 have an intermediate response, with 50%-80% achieving spontaneous remission.
  • Among healthy adults (as this patient), acute HBV infection is self-limited in >95% of cases.

Serological markers help clarify stages of infection.  Acute HBV infection is characterized by positive hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), hepatitis B e antigen (an indicator of high infectivity), IgM hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc or HBcAb), and detectable HBV DNA.  For the majority of patients who contract HBV as an adult and clear the infection, serology typically demonstrates hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb or anti-HBs, which provides immunity), IgG anti-HBc, and hepatitis B e antigen antibody (anti-HBe) (Recovery phase in the Table).  Anti-HBe can eventually wane and may not be present later.  The latter 2 antibodies are markers for prior infection (vaccinated individuals are exposed only to HBsAg) and are also seen in patients with chronic HBV infection.  Patients with chronic active infection also have the continued presence of HBsAg in their serum.

(Choice A)  Following acute exposure to HBV, HBsAg alone can be seen 1-2 weeks before the onset of symptoms or the development of other serological markers, as seen in the exhibit.

(Choice C)  Because the hepatitis B vaccine is typically made with HBV surface proteins (not core proteins), vaccinated individuals have only positive serology for HBsAb.

(Choice D)  Patients who have been exposed to HBV have circulating HBcAb (IgM in acute infection and IgG in chronic HBV), and circulating HBsAg signifies the presence of active infection (eg, chronic carrier).

(Choice E)  The lone presence of IgM HBcAb (and occasionally IgG HBcAb) is usually suggestive of the window period, which occurs after the disappearance of HBsAg but before the appearance of HBsAb.  Isolated IgG HBcAb can also be seen when either HBsAb or HBsAg has become undetectable in immune or chronically infected individuals, respectively.

Educational objective:
Among healthy adults, acute hepatitis B virus infection is self-limited in >95% of cases.  In the recovery phase, serology typically demonstrates hepatitis B surface antibody (which provides immunity), IgG hepatitis B core antibody, and hepatitis B e antigen antibody.

questionList.title: Hepatitis b

answerChoiceList.choice: +−−
−++
−+−
+−+
−−+
