questionList.questionText: A 19-year-old man comes to the office with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and sore throat.  He has no diarrhea or rash.  The patient has no significant medical history.  He occasionally uses tobacco and alcohol; he has smoked marijuana several times but has never used injectable drugs.  The patient is sexually active with one partner and uses condoms occasionally.  Temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 16/min.  Physical examination shows enlarged tonsils with white exudates.  Enlarged, tender, mobile nodes are palpable along the cervical, axillary, and inguinal chains bilaterally.  The examination is otherwise unremarkable.  Which of the following tests is most likely to yield the diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Infectious mononucleosis

Etiology

  • Epstein-Barr virus (most common)

Clinical features

  • Fever
  • Tonsillitis/pharyngitis ± exudates
  • Posterior or diffuse cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Significant fatigue
  • ± Hepatosplenomegaly
  • ± Rash after amoxicillin

Diagnostic findings

  • Positive heterophile antibody (Monospot) test
    • 25% false-negative rate during 1st week of illness
  • Atypical lymphocytosis
  • Transient hepatitis

Management

  • Due to risk of splenic rupture:
    • Avoid sports for ≥3 weeks
    • Avoid contact sports for ≥4 weeks

This patient's symptoms are suspicious for infectious mononucleosis (IM), which is typically caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).  IM is classically characterized by a prolonged course (up to 1 month) of fever, exudative pharyngitis, and tender lymphadenopathy; the adenopathy is commonly located in the posterior cervical region but may be generalized, as in this case.  Fatigue is common and may persist for months, beyond the resolution of other symptoms.  In addition, splenomegaly occurs in the majority of patients, and splenic rupture is a rare but dangerous complication.

Diagnosis is with the heterophile antibody (Monospot) test, which is a specific test that detects EBV antibodies that agglutinate to horse red blood cells.  Heterophile antibodies arise within a week of symptoms (25% false-negative rate during the first week of illness) and persist for up to a year.  The heterophile antibody test is not accurate in children age <4, for whom serum anti-EBV antibody testing is recommended instead.

(Choice A)  Cytomegalovirus (CMV) causes a constellation of symptoms similar to IM.  However, IM caused by EBV is much more common, and pharyngitis is less commonly seen in CMV.

(Choice C)  Acute HIV infection also causes fever, malaise, and generalized lymphadenopathy, and testing should be performed in this patient.  However, adenopathy in acute HIV is nontender and tonsillar exudates are uncommon.  In addition, rash and diarrhea are present in most patients with acute HIV.  Therefore, IM is a more likely diagnosis.

(Choice D)  Lymph node biopsy is indicated when there is high suspicion for malignancy, such as a patient with fever, weight loss, and nontender lymphadenopathy.  Tender, mobile nodes are more suggestive of infection than malignancy.

(Choice E)  Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted infection that can present as an extragenital infection (eg, conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, arthritis).  Isolated gonococcal pharyngitis is not typically associated with systemic symptoms (eg, fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, malaise) as seen in this patient.

(Choice F)  A rapid streptococcal antigen test is positive in streptococcal pharyngitis, which can cause fever, pharyngitis, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy.  However, streptococcal pharyngitis is unlikely to cause generalized lymphadenopathy, and symptoms typically resolve within a week even without treatment.  This patient's prolonged symptoms are more likely due to EBV.

Educational objective:
Infectious mononucleosis causes prolonged fever, pharyngitis, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy and is diagnosed by the heterophile antibody (Monospot) test.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Infectious mononucleosis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: How to use … the Monospot and other heterophile antibody tests.
Primary Epstein-Barr virus infection.

questionList.questionText: An 11-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to a rash.  The rash developed on the patient's face yesterday and has now spread over her entire body.  The parents say that she has been sick for the past 3 days with fever, cough, runny nose, and "pink eye."  The patient has no other medical conditions and has received all age-appropriate vaccinations as of age 6 months.  Approximately 3 weeks ago, the family returned from a trip to Yemen for her grandfather's funeral.  Temperature is 39.6 C (103.3 F).  Other vital signs are normal for age.  The patient appears tired and irritable with dry mucous membranes.  The conjunctivae are injected without discharge.  There is a blanching, erythematous, maculopapular rash covering the face and entire body except for the palms and soles.  Which of the following is most effective in preventing nosocomial transmission in the care of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Measles virus (rubeola)

Transmission

  • Airborne respiratory particles

Clinical features

  • Prodrome (eg, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, fever, Koplik spots)
  • Maculopapular exanthem
    • Cephalocaudal & centrifugal spread
    • Usually spares palms & soles

Management

  • Supportive care
  • Vitamin A

Complications

  • Pneumonia
  • Neurologic
    • Encephalitis (days)
    • Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (weeks)
    • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (years)

Prevention

  • Live attenuated vaccine

This infant with a maculopapular rash after a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis likely has measles.  The rash begins on the face and spreads cephalocaudally and often evolves from blanching lesions to a confluent, nonblanching rash; the palms and soles are usually spared but can be involved in atypical cases.

Measles virus is highly contagious and can cause outbreaks in unvaccinated persons.  Symptoms manifest 1-3 weeks after inhalation of infectious respiratory particles, which can remain suspended in air for hours in a closed space (eg, treatment room) due to their small size (≤5 µm).  Measles can also spread via direct contact of these particles with a mucosal surface (eg, mouth, eyes).  Patients with known or suspected measles should be isolated and cared for according to airborne precautions (eg, negative pressure room, N95 face mask for health care personnel).  The virus is most contagious during the prodrome stage, but patients can spread disease for several days after the rash appears.

The best way to prevent measles infection in children is administration of 2 doses of the measles vaccine, once at age 1 year and again at age 4 years.  This schedule generates immunity in >95% of children.  For planned international travel, an additional dose between age 6 months and age 11 months is also recommended.  This patient has not yet received the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine and likely acquired the virus during international travel to a high-risk region.

(Choice B)  Droplet precautions (eg, surgical mask) are indicated to reduce transmission of infectious agents spread via relatively larger (>5 µm) respiratory particles.  These particles are typically dispersed over short distances and remain suspended in air only briefly, as with the influenza virus.  Droplet precautions do not prevent the spread of smaller airborne particles associated with the measles virus.

(Choice C)  Postexposure antibiotic prophylaxis for health care workers can decrease the transmission of specific bacteria (eg, Bordetella pertussis) but has no role in preventing viral disease.

(Choice D)  There is no universal postexposure antiviral medication for measles; the measles vaccine or immunoglobulin may be considered for exposed health care workers without documented measles immunity.

(Choice E)  Vitamin A deficiency is associated with increased morbidity from measles infection.  Vitamin A supplementation is recommended to reduce complications but does not affect transmission of the virus.

Educational objective:
Measles is characterized by a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by a diffuse maculopapular rash.  This highly contagious virus is transmitted via small respiratory particles and requires airborne precautions.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Measles

answerChoiceList.choice: Postexposure antibiotic for all health care workers
Postexposure antiviral for all health care workers

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Measles.

questionList.questionText: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of a bite on her right arm by her neighbors' dog.  The neighbors accompany the patient with their dog, which is not immunized against rabies but appears healthy.  The patient has no other medical conditions and takes no medications.  Her last tetanus booster was 3 years ago.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 12/min.  On her right forearm is a shallow bite wound that is 1 cm long with no erythema or purulent drainage.  The wound is cleaned with soap, water, and povidone-iodine solution, and antibiotic prophylaxis is initiated.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Rabies is a fatal disease transmitted by a bite from an infected mammal.  In developing countries, dogs account for >90% of transmissions due to inadequate rabies control programs.  In contrast, rabies is rare in dogs in the United States due to widespread vaccination.  Most rabies cases in the United States are due to bites from wild animals (eg, bats, raccoons).

For patients who have not previously received rabies vaccination, postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) consists of rabies immunoglobulin plus a series of rabies immunizations.  However, the decision to administer PEP is guided by a variety of factors, as follows:

  • Patients bitten by high-risk wild animals (eg, bats, raccoons, foxes, skunks) should receive PEP if the animal is unavailable for testing.  Because bat bites can go unrecognized, PEP is also recommended following direct exposure to bats (unless the patient is certain a bite or scratch was not inflicted).  In the rare situation that the high-risk wild animal is available for testing, PEP can be withheld until the animal is euthanized and its brain is tested for rabies.

  • Patients bitten by pets in the United States do not require PEP if the animal appears healthy and is available for quarantine (as in this case).  Contagious animals (ie, rabies virus present in saliva) are symptomatic within 5-10 days; therefore, pets can be observed for 10 days for signs of rabies without administering PEP immediately (Choice D).  However, if the pet is unavailable for quarantine or is symptomatic, PEP should be administered.

  • Patients bitten by low-risk animals (eg, squirrels, chipmunks) do not need PEP.

All wounds should also be thoroughly cleaned with a viricidal agent such as povidone-iodine.

(Choices A and B)  An asymptomatic, healthy dog can be observed for 10 days for signs of rabies.  There is no need to euthanize it for testing because there have been no rabies cases in the United States due to a cat or dog that has been observed for 10 days.

(Choice E)  Patients with bites from high-risk wild animals or certain domestic animals (eg, dog, cat, ferret) should start PEP if the animal is unavailable.  However, if the animal is available, either observation (pets) or testing (wild animals) should be performed before deciding on PEP.

Educational objective:
For patients who have not previously received the rabies vaccination, rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) includes rabies vaccine and rabies immunoglobulin.  PEP is indicated when a domestic (eg, dog, cat, ferret) or high-risk (eg, bat, racoon, fox, skunk) animal is unavailable for observation or testing.  Available, asymptomatic animals can either be observed (pets, for 10 days) or tested (wild animals) to determine the need for PEP.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Rabies

answerChoiceList.choice: Euthanize the dog and examine its brain for rabies; provide immediate rabies prophylaxis for the patient
Euthanize the dog and examine its brain for rabies; provide rabies prophylaxis for the patient if positive
Observe the dog for 10 days for signs of rabies; no immediate rabies prophylaxis for the patient
Observe the dog for 10 days for signs of rabies; provide immediate rabies prophylaxis for the patient
Release the dog without observation or testing; provide immediate rabies prophylaxis for the patient

Use of a reduced (4-dose) vaccine schedule for postexposure prophylaxis to prevent human rabies: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices.

questionList.questionText:
A 10-month-old girl is brought to the office due to a rash.  The patient has had a low-grade fever for the past 3 days that has been controlled with acetaminophen.  A rash developed on her face 2 days ago and has since spread to her chest, abdomen, and extremities.  The patient has had no cough, rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, vomiting, or diarrhea.  She has otherwise been healthy.  The patient has received all routine, age-appropriate vaccinations and takes no medications.  Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Physical examination shows a playful infant with small, tender lymph nodes in the suboccipital, posterior auricular, and posterior cervical areas.  There is patchy erythema on the soft palate.  The rash is shown in the image below.  A similar-appearing rash is present on the face.

The remainder of the examination is normal.  Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with this patient's presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
Rubella

Clinical presentation

  • Congenital:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
    • Cataracts
    • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Children:
    • Fever
    • Cephalocaudal spread of maculopapular rash
  • Adolescents/Adults:  
    • Same as children + arthralgia/arthritis

Diagnosis

  • Serology

Prevention

  • Live attenuated rubella vaccine

This playful and well-appearing infant has fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy, findings that can be seen with rubella infection.  Rubella is a mild viral illness that children are typically immunized against at age 12 months and age 4 years with the live measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine; this 10-month-old patient's age-appropriate vaccinations would not include protection against rubella.

Symptoms of rubella develop 2-3 weeks after inhalation of infected respiratory droplets.  Patients may be asymptomatic or have initial symptoms of low-grade fever and lymphadenopathy, particularly suboccipital, posterior auricular, and posterior cervical.  A fine, pink, maculopapular exanthem begins on the face, spreads quickly in a cephalocaudal pattern to the rest of the body, and lasts <3 days.  Some patients also have petechiae or erythematous papules, known as Forchheimer spots, on the soft palate.  Treatment is supportive.

Although postnatal infection (as in this patient) is mild, prenatal infection can result in spontaneous abortion, fetal demise, or congenital rubella syndrome.

(Choice A)  Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19 and classically presents in school-aged children with prodromal symptoms (eg, fever, rhinorrhea) followed by a "slapped cheek" rash and a lacy or reticular rash on the body.  The rash typically does not appear until prodromal symptoms have resolved.  In addition, palatal lesions and posterior auricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy are not typical.

(Choice B)  Patients with Kawasaki disease (KD) have fever for ≥5 days with 4 of the following: conjunctivitis, mucositis, rash, extremity edema, and lymphadenopathy (node >1.5 cm).  This patient has had only a rash and fever for 3 days, and does not have conjunctivitis or extremity edema, making KD less likely.

(Choice C)  Measles causes a maculopapular rash that spreads cephalocaudally and, after a few days, coalesces and darkens (eg, reddish-brown).  Patients are ill-appearing with high fever up to 40 C (104 F), coryza, and cough, none of which are present in this patient.

(Choice E)  Scarlet fever is a streptococcal infection that can cause fever, palatal petechiae, and a "sandpaper" texture rash.  However, the rash usually begins and is most prominent along skinfolds (eg, axillae, groin) and then spreads to the trunk and extremities.  In addition, the diagnosis is rare for patients under age 3.

Educational objective:
Rubella is a mild illness characterized by low-grade fever, lymphadenopathy (particularly suboccipital, posterior auricular, and posterior cervical), and a maculopapular exanthem that spreads cephalocaudally.  Forchheimer spots (ie, erythematous papules on the soft palate) may be seen.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Rubella

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Common childhood viral infections.
Rubella.

questionList.questionText: A 1-day-old girl is in the neonatal intensive care unit due to low birth weight.  She was born at 36 weeks gestation to a 25-year-old woman via a precipitous spontaneous vaginal delivery.  The patient required minimal manual stimulation after delivery and had a subsequent strong cry.  Apgar scores were 5 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.  Weight, length, and head circumference are <3rd percentile.  The red reflex is absent bilaterally, and both pupils appear cloudy.  A continuous, harsh murmur is best heard over the left upper sternal border.  The abdomen is nondistended and nontender.  The liver and spleen are enlarged.  Tone is normal, and Moro reflex and palmar grasp reflex are intact.  Which of the following maternal factors is most commonly associated with this patient's presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
Rubella

Clinical presentation

  • Congenital:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
    • Cataracts
    • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Children:
    • Fever
    • Cephalocaudal spread of maculopapular rash
  • Adolescents/Adults:  
    • Same as children + arthralgia/arthritis

Diagnosis

  • Serology

Prevention

  • Live attenuated rubella vaccine

This patient has symmetric growth restriction and hepatosplenomegaly, nonspecific findings of congenital infection.  The continuous, harsh murmur is consistent with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and cloudy pupils with absent red reflexes are suggestive of cataracts; these features raise suspicion for congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).  Sensorineural hearing loss is another characteristic feature typically identified on routine newborn hearing screen before hospital discharge.

Rubella is transmitted transplacentally, and the risk for developing significant fetal defects is highest during the first trimester.  Although prenatal maternal infection may present with a self-limited illness (eg, fever, joint pain, rash), many adults are asymptomatic, which was likely the case in this mother.

Because most mothers in the United States received the measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine series during childhood, rubella is uncommon.  Lack of childhood vaccinations and resulting lack of maternal immunity increase the possibility for an unvaccinated mother to give birth to a neonate with CRS.  The live attenuated rubella vaccine should be given to all nonpregnant, nonimmune women of childbearing age prior to conception because live attenuated vaccines carry the potential risk for viral transmission to the fetus if given during pregnancy.

(Choice A)  Avoiding cat litter, which can harbor Toxoplasmosis gondii from feces of infected cats, during pregnancy can prevent congenital toxoplasmosis.  Symptoms include growth restriction and hepatosplenomegaly, but chorioretinitis and jaundice would also be expected.  Cataracts and PDA are not classic findings.

(Choice B)  Fetal alcohol syndrome, caused by prenatal alcohol consumption, presents with growth restriction, CNS anomalies, and facial dysmorphisms.  Heart defects can occur, but hepatosplenomegaly and cataracts are not seen.

(Choice C)  Prenatal or perinatal transmission of sexually transmitted infections causes various findings, such as vesicular skin lesions (neonatal herpes simplex) or hepatomegaly and jaundice (congenital syphilis).  This patient's PDA and cataracts are classic for CRS.

(Choice D)  Prenatal ingestion of unpasteurized products increases risk for Listeria monocytogenes infection, which can present as neonatal sepsis or meningoencephalitis, not cardiac and ophthalmic abnormalities.

(Choice F)  Infants born to mothers with poorly controlled pregestational diabetes mellitus are at increased risk for congenital heart disease (most commonly transposition of the great vessels).  However, cataracts and hepatosplenomegaly would not be seen.

Educational objective:
Congenital rubella syndrome classically presents with cataracts, patent ductus arteriosus, and sensorineural hearing loss; symmetric growth restriction and hepatosplenomegaly are nonspecific findings.  Prevention is with maternal vaccination before conception.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Rubella

answerChoiceList.choice: Exposure to a sexually transmitted infection

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Congenital rubella.

questionList.questionText: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, at 38 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to regular, painful contractions.  The contractions began an hour ago immediately after the patient experienced a "gush" of fluid.  She has had no vaginal bleeding, and fetal movement has been normal.  The patient's most recent prenatal visit was 6 weeks ago.  She has no known medical conditions and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs.  Vital signs are normal.  Fetal heart rate tracing shows a baseline of 140/min with multiple accelerations and no decelerations.  The tocodynamometer shows contractions occurring every 3-4 minutes.  On pelvic examination, a cluster of clear vesicles with an erythematous base is noted on the right labium minus.  Speculum examination shows a pool of clear fluid in the posterior vagina.  The cervix is 6 cm dilated and 100% effaced with the fetal head at the −1 station.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has an active genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which typically presents as painful vesicles on an erythematous base that evolve into shallow, open ulcers or erosions.  Maternal HSV infection can cause neonatal infection, which can be devastating due to significant morbidity (eg, seizures, developmental delay, blindness) and mortality.

HSV can be vertically transmitted transplacentally (typically with a primary infection); however, the most common route of transmission is during vaginal delivery because the fetus is exposed to HSV during passage through the birth canal.  The risk of transmission is proportional to the amount of viral shedding, which is highest during the time prodromal symptoms (eg, burning) and active lesions are present.  Therefore, patients with either prodromal symptoms or active genital HSV lesions at delivery (eg, active labor, as in this patient) cannot undergo vaginal delivery and require immediate cesarean delivery.

Patients who had an HSV outbreak prior to or during pregnancy should generally begin suppressive therapy (eg, acyclovir) starting at 36 weeks gestation to reduce the risk of viral shedding in the peripartum period.  When no active lesions or prodromal symptoms are present at labor, vaginal delivery can often be undertaken in this population.

(Choice A)  Vertical HSV transmission risk increases with the length of time since membrane rupture, so tocolytic administration, which is designed to prolong pregnancy, is not recommended.

(Choices B and C)  In contrast to this patient, individuals who have a history of genital herpes but have no prodromal symptoms or active lesions at delivery can undergo vaginal delivery because maternal viral shedding and the risk of vertical transmission are minimal.

(Choice E)  Fetal scalp electrodes are avoided in patients with HSV because they cut the fetal skin and create a possible portal for HSV, thereby increasing the risk of vertical transmission.

(Choice F)  Women who have a history of genital HSV receive prophylactic antiviral therapy (eg, acyclovir, valacyclovir) from 36 weeks gestation until delivery to reduce the risk of active lesions at delivery and the need for cesarean delivery.  Initiating antiviral therapy at delivery is unlikely to have an immediate effect on viral replication; it is not indicated because it does not decrease the risk of neonatal HSV infection.

Educational objective:
Cesarean delivery is indicated in women with active genital herpes lesions at delivery to reduce the risk for neonatal herpes simplex virus infection.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: HSV infection

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Herpes simplex virus and pregnancy: a review of the management of antenatal and peripartum herpes infections.
Preventing herpes simplex virus in the newborn.
Herpes simplex virus infection during pregnancy.

questionList.questionText: A 1-year-old boy is seen in the clinic for a rash.  He had fever 3 days ago and has also had a runny nose.  The mother gave him ibuprofen, and the following day the rash appeared on his cheeks and chest and has spread to his abdomen, back, and extremities.  The mother describes the rash as being raised red bumps initially; they are now fluid-filled lesions.  Clusters of new lesions continue to arise, and the patient scratches constantly.  He is not eating or drinking as much as usual but is still making wet diapers.  He attends day care, and another child had a similar rash that crusted over.  The patient has no medical conditions and received his vaccinations in infancy, but he has not yet received his 1-year vaccines.  Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F); the other vital signs are normal.  The rash is shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Chickenpox (varicella)

Epidemiology

  • Primary infection with VZV
  • Transmission via direct contact or airborne respiratory particles
  • High risk: adolescents, adults, individuals who are immunocompromised, women who are pregnant, newborns

Clinical features

  • Prodrome (eg, fever, malaise)
  • Pruritic macules, papules & vesicles in successive crops at different stages
  • Complications: skin infection, pneumonia, encephalitis

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • VZV PCR in atypical cases

Treatment

  • Supportive (eg, antihistamines)
  • Acyclovir for high-risk patients & complicated disease

Prevention

  • 2 doses of VZV vaccine (age 1 & 4)

VZV = varicella-zoster virus.

This patient has fever and diffuse, pruritic papulovesicular lesions concerning for chickenpox, or primary varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection.  Although the incidence of chickenpox has decreased with the live varicella vaccine (administered at age 1 and 4), unimmunized individuals, like this patient who has not had his 1-year vaccines, are at high risk of infection.  Transmission rate is >90% in susceptible individuals after exposure, and this child was likely exposed to VZV by the child with a similar rash.

Chickenpox presents with a viral prodrome (eg, fever, runny nose) followed by a pruritic, generalized rash.  The rash often begins as maculopapular and evolves into pustules and/or vesicles that rupture and crust.  Clusters of lesions in different stages of progression are characteristic.

Diagnosis of varicella is typically clinical with no additional testing required.  In cases that are atypical (eg, mild or breakthrough disease in partially vaccinated patients) or severe (eg, immunocompromised patients), the preferred diagnostic method is VZV PCR testing (eg, skin lesion, blood, cerebrospinal fluid).  Treatment is generally supportive (eg, antipyretics, antihistamines) in young, healthy children; acyclovir is reserved for older children (age ≥12), adults, and immunocompromised patients who are at risk for severe disease.

(Choice A)  Impetigo can present with vesicles and/or pustules, and bacterial culture can confirm the causative organism (eg, Staphylococcus aureus).  However, the lesions are usually localized (not diffuse); a honey-colored crust would be expected, and fever is atypical.  In patients with VZV infection, viral culture is less sensitive than PCR testing and is not recommended for diagnosis.

(Choice C)  Skin prick allergy testing can identify a medication (eg, ibuprofen) allergy.  In contrast to this patient's presentation, an allergic reaction presents within 1-2 hours of allergen exposure with pruritic plaques (ie, hives).

(Choice D)  Skin scraping and microscopy can confirm scabies, which presents with pruritic papules or vesicles.  Although scabies typically involves the wrists, finger webs, axillae, and groin, it can be diffuse in young children.  However, systemic symptoms (eg, fever, poor appetite) would not be present, making this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice E)  Varicella-specific IgG can confirm VZV immunity postinfection or postvaccination but would be negative during the acute illness.  In addition, IgM serology is less sensitive than PCR testing and is not typically used for diagnosis.

Educational objective:
Chickenpox typically presents with a viral prodrome followed by a diffuse pruritic rash in different stages of progression (eg, macules, papules, vesicles).  Diagnosis is clinical, and treatment in young, healthy children is generally supportive.

questionList.title: Chicken pox

questionList.questionText: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to fever and facial pain.  Two days ago, fever, myalgias, and fatigue began.  This morning, pain and fullness developed in the right cheek.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions and takes no daily medications.  Immunizations are not up to date, but the family cannot remember which ones were missed.  The patient is in high school and is on the school track team.  He has a girlfriend but is not sexually active.  He does not drink, smoke, or use illicit drugs.  Temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F).  Examination reveals an alert, uncomfortable-appearing adolescent.  Tenderness and fullness are present in the right cheek, which obscures the angle of the mandible.  Bilateral tympanic membranes are clear.  The oropharynx has no erythema, exudate, or tonsillar enlargement.  No cervical lymph nodes are palpable.  This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
questionList.explanationText:
This teenager with parotitis following a nonspecific prodrome of fever, myalgias, and fatigue likely has mumps.  This contagious viral illness is usually self-limited, but serious complications (due to systemic spread of the virus) are possible.  The virus has an affinity for glandular epithelium and classically causes parotitis, which can be unilateral or bilateral.  Orchitis, a common complication, can develop in infected adolescent boys and young adults and impair fertility.  Pancreatitis has been described in infected children and adults.  The virus is neurotropic and can cause aseptic meningitis (generally benign) and sensorineural hearing loss (often transient but can lead to deafness).

Immunization against mumps is provided by the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine.  Among unvaccinated children, mumps is most common in school-age children, who often have mild disease or are asymptomatic.  Symptoms are more severe and complications are more likely among unvaccinated adolescents and adults.  Vaccinated patients are more likely to present in late adolescence or early adulthood as immunity wanes.

(Choice A)  Glomerulonephritis can follow streptococcal pharyngitis or cellulitis.  This patient has no signs or symptoms of pharyngitis, and group A Streptococcus is a rare cause of parotitis.

(Choice B)  Mumps is not associated with hepatitis in immunocompetent patients.

(Choice C)  Primary infection with HIV can present with parotitis and subsequently lead to CD4+ T-cell depletion.  This teenager is not sexually active and does not use intravenous drugs, making acute HIV infection extremely unlikely.

(Choice D)  Myositis, particularly of the calves or thighs, can be a complication of influenza.  Influenza presents with fever, myalgias, and pharyngitis, often with lower respiratory tract infection, but is a rare cause of parotitis.

(Choice F)  Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause mononucleosis, a syndrome that includes fever, pharyngitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy.  Mononucleosis can be complicated by splenomegaly and, in severe cases, splenic rupture.  EBV is also a common cause of viral parotitis; however, the absence of pharyngitis or cervical adenopathy in this teenager makes EBV infection unlikely.

Educational objective:
Mumps presents with fever and parotitis.  Although mumps is generally self-limited, complications can include orchitis, aseptic meningitis, pancreatitis, and deafness.  Complications are more common in older or unvaccinated individuals.

questionList.title: Mumps

questionList.questionText:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate with confusion and agitation for the last 2 days.  While in the emergency department, he has generalized tonic-clonic seizures.  The patient's other medical problems include alcohol use disorder and recreational drug use.  He was hospitalized 6 months ago for alcoholic pancreatitis.  His temperature is 40.0 C (104.0 F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 105/min.  He is confused and disoriented.  Funduscopy is within normal limits, and there is no neck stiffness.  Neurologic examination shows upgoing plantar reflexes bilaterally.  CT scan of the head reveals no abnormalities.  Lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis results are as follows:

Opening pressureNormal
Protein85 mg/dL
Red blood cells25/mm3
Leukocytes90/mm3
Lymphocytes90%

Gram stain shows no bacteria.  Further cerebrospinal fluid studies are pending.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis

Clinical findings

  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Seizure
  • Altered mental status (eg, confusion, agitation)
  • ± Focal neurologic findings (eg, hemiparesis, cranial nerve palsies, ataxia)

Diagnostic findings

  • CSF analysis:
    • ↑ WBCs (↑ lymphocytes), ↑ RBCs
    • ↑ Protein, normal glucose
    • HSV DNA on PCR
  • Brain MRI: temporal lobe hemorrhage/edema

Treatment

  • Intravenous acyclovir

CSF = cerebrospinal fluid; WBCs = white blood cells; RBCs = red blood cells.

This patient's presentation is consistent with viral encephalitis.  The majority of acute viral encephalitis cases are due to unknown causes.  However, herpes viruses (eg, herpes simplex, varicella, Epstein-Barr) most commonly cause encephalitis in immunocompetent adults.  Patients typically present with fever, altered mental status, agitation, headaches, and seizures that can rapidly progress to complete unresponsiveness or coma.  Examination can show neurologic abnormalities, including hemiparesis, cranial nerve palsies, and exaggerated deep-tendon reflexes.  Clinical signs of meningeal irritation (eg, photophobia, nuchal rigidity) are usually absent in patients with pure encephalitis.

Lumbar puncture usually shows cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings of elevated white blood cell count with lymphocytic predominance, normal to slightly elevated protein concentration (generally 100 mg/dL), and normal glucose.  Most patients have an increased red blood cell count as well.  Diagnosis is usually confirmed by detecting viral DNA by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in the CSF.  Empiric treatment with intravenous acyclovir should be started while awaiting PCR results as encephalitis is often associated with significant morbidity and mortality.

(Choice B)  Intravenous amphotericin (plus flucytosine) is used for induction therapy in patients with cryptococcal meningoencephalitis.  Cryptococcal meningitis is usually a subacute meningitis, and patients commonly present after weeks of symptoms.  It is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients (eg, those with HIV).  Symptoms are due to increased intracranial pressures (headache) from capsular swelling; almost all patients have markedly elevated opening pressure on spinal tap.  This patient's rapid onset of symptoms, presentation more consistent with encephalitis, and normal opening pressure make cryptococcal meningitis very unlikely.

(Choice C)  Intravenous ceftriaxone and vancomycin (and ampicillin in adults age >50) are empiric treatments for bacterial meningitis.  CSF analysis in these patients typically shows elevated white blood cell counts with neutrophil predominance, elevated protein concentration (often >250 mg/dL), and low glucose.

(Choice D)  CT scan of the head does not always show abnormalities in patients with encephalitis and is typically done to exclude a space-occupying lesion.  MRI of the brain is sensitive for detection of demyelination or other focal abnormalities of the temporal lobe that suggest herpes simplex virus encephalitis.  However, empiric treatment with intravenous acyclovir should be started as soon as possible in patients with suspected viral encephalitis without waiting for further imaging studies.

(Choice E)  Chlordiazepoxide is used to treat alcohol withdrawal in hospitalized patients.  Withdrawal can begin within 1-2 days of stopping alcohol and presents with tremulousness, anxiety, headache, and palpitations.  These can progress to fever, hypertension, and delirium tremens.  This patient's CSF findings (eg, elevated protein & WBC), however, are more suggestive of viral encephalitis.

Educational objective:
Viral encephalitis can present with cerebrospinal fluid findings of elevated white blood cell count with a lymphocytic predominance, elevated red blood cell count, normal glucose, and normal to slightly elevated protein concentration.  Early empiric therapy with intravenous acyclovir should be initiated as soon as possible for suspected herpes simplex virus encephalitis until confirmatory tests return.

questionList.title: HSV infection

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Viral encephalitis.

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 2 years
Sex Assigned at Birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department

History
Chief Concern: brought in by his babysitter for "noisy breathing"
History of Present Illness:
• rhinorrhea, congestion, and cough for 2 days
• cough worsened last night with new-onset, high-pitched inspiratory noise that gets worse when he cries
• 6-year-old brother also has cold symptoms
Past Medical History:
• unremarkable
Medications:
• none
Vaccinations:
• unknown
Allergies:
• no known drug allergies
Family History:
• noncontributory

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
38 C
(100.4 F)		140/min44/min–96%
on RA		–––

• Appearance: alert and calm with an intermittent, harsh, dry cough
• HEENT: neck supple; mild pharyngeal erythema without tonsillar enlargement
• Pulmonary: clear to auscultation; mild subcostal retractions
• Cardiac: regular rhythm, no murmur

Diagnostic Studies
• none

Question
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Acute stridor in children

Peak age

Additional clinical features

X-ray findings

Croup*

6 months to 3 years

  • Fever, barking cough
  • Responsive to racemic epinephrine
  • Subglottic narrowing (symmetric)

Laryngotracheal foreign body

1 to 3 years

  • Sudden onset choking & cough
  • No fever
  • Subglottic density or swelling

Retropharyngeal abscess

2 to 4 years

  • Fever, dysphagia, drooling, neck stiffness/swelling, muffled voice
  • Widened prevertebral space

Epiglottitis

<5 years

  • Fever, dysphagia, drooling, sore throat, tripod positioning
  • Rapidly progressive respiratory distress
  • Enlarged epiglottis

Bacterial tracheitis

<6 years

  • Fever, cough
  • Rapidly progressive respiratory distress
  • Nonresponsive to racemic epinephrine
  • Subglottic narrowing (irregular tracheal borders)

*Also known as laryngotracheobronchitis.

URI = upper respiratory infection.

This generally well-appearing patient with acute onset of stridor (high-pitched inspiratory noise) in the setting of fever and upper respiratory tract symptoms (eg, rhinorrhea, congestion) most likely has croup, or laryngotracheitis.

Croup is a respiratory infection that is most commonly caused by parainfluenza virus and typically affects young children (age 6 months to 3 years).  The illness usually begins with nonspecific upper respiratory tract symptoms and progresses to characteristic findings of hoarseness, stridor, and a barking, seal-like cough due to upper airway edema.  The stridor is typically inspiratory (may be biphasic in severe cases) but may not be detected if the child is calm, as seen in this case, because patients with mild croup develop stridor only when airway narrowing is exacerbated by agitation (eg, crying) or excitement.  The lungs are usually clear to auscultation, and fever may be present.  Lower airway signs (eg, wheezing) or rapid clinical deterioration suggests an alternate diagnosis.

The diagnosis of croup is made clinically, and treatment includes a corticosteroid to reduce subglottic edema as well as nebulized racemic epinephrine for severe cases (ie, stridor at rest).

(Choices A and D)  Bacterial tracheitis and epiglottitis are rare, severe upper airway infections that cause stridor and are classically caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Haemophilus influenzae type b, respectively.  Patients typically appear ill and have high fever, persistent stridor, and marked and progressive respiratory distress.  This patient's mild respiratory distress with only intermittent stridor makes a bacterial upper airway infection unlikely.  In addition, cough does not occur with epiglottitis.

(Choice B)  Bronchiolitis is a lower respiratory tract illness that presents at age <2 with fever, cough, and congestion.  However, expiratory wheezing and crackles would be expected, not inspiratory stridor.

(Choice E)  Foreign body aspiration often presents after a choking episode with sudden-onset respiratory distress or stridor.  This patient has stridor in the setting of infectious signs and symptoms (ie, fever, congestion, rhinorrhea), which makes croup more likely.

(Choice F)  Retropharyngeal abscess is a deep neck space infection that presents with fever, dysphagia, neck pain/stiffness, and a muffled voice.  A large abscess compromising the airway can lead to stridor, but posterior pharyngeal swelling would be expected on examination, and cough does not occur.

Educational objective:
Croup is a common viral respiratory infection that should be suspected in a young child (age 6 months to 3 years) with acute-onset stridor and a harsh, barking cough in the setting of infectious signs and symptoms (eg, fever, rhinorrhea).

questionList.title: Laryngotracheobronchitis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Laryngotracheobronchitis.

questionList.questionText: A neonate is evaluated in the nursery an hour after delivery.  The patient was born via a term vaginal delivery to a 20-year-old primigravid woman who had routine prenatal care.  The mother developed a fever 2 days ago and a vesicular rash on her face and chest yesterday.  On the day of delivery, the rash spread to her abdomen and became intensely pruritic.  She went into labor later that day and delivered the neonate without difficulty.  Skin-to-skin contact between the mother and neonate was deferred due to the maternal rash.  Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.  The patient weighs 2.95 kg (6 lb 8 oz).  Vital signs and physical examination are normal.  The mother does not recall having similar symptoms previously.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this neonate?
questionList.explanationText:
This mother's fever and pruritic, vesicular rash are consistent with a primary outbreak of varicella-zoster virus (VZV), or chickenpox.  VZV is transmitted via airborne respiratory particles or contact with vesicular fluid and is extremely contagious.

Although the majority of children with VZV have uncomplicated disease, neonates are at increased risk for severe infection due to immature T-cell function.  Findings can vary from mild chickenpox (eg, fever, vesicular rash) to disseminated disease (eg, pneumonia, hepatitis, encephalitis), more commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.  The highest risk for severe disease and increased mortality is exposure to maternal infection immediately surrounding delivery because it is unlikely for the mother to develop and pass on antibodies to the child before birth.

Therefore, postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is recommended for neonates born to a mother with VZV infection from 5 days before to 2 days after delivery.  Although the varicella vaccine is recommended as PEP for nonimmune children age ≥1, this live virus vaccine is contraindicated in neonates, and neonatal PEP is achieved by administering passive immunization with varicella-zoster immune globulin (VariZIG) (Choice C).  VariZIG is also indicated for other nonimmune, high-risk patients who cannot receive the VZV vaccine, including pregnant and immunocompromised patients.

(Choice A)  Prophylactic acyclovir can be given as an adjunct to VariZIG in some high-risk cases, but its use alone is generally not preferred due to limited proven efficacy.  Acyclovir is also used to treat neonates who develop signs of varicella disease (eg, fever, rash) but is not indicated in this asymptomatic patient.

(Choice D)  Varicella IgG antibodies can confirm immunity.  However, because IgG takes 2-3 weeks to develop after symptom onset, this asymptomatic infant whose mother very recently developed infection has neither produced antibodies nor received maternal antibodies via transplacental transfer.  Measurement of antibodies prior to VariZIG administration is not recommended.

(Choice E)  Isolation of the neonate from the infected mother should occur until the mother is no longer contagious (ie, lesions crusted over).  However, because the neonate was exposed to the virus during delivery, passive immunoprophylaxis with VariZIG is also required.

Educational objective:
Postexposure prophylaxis is indicated for neonates born to mothers who develop chickenpox 5 days before to 2 days after delivery.  Because the live varicella vaccine is contraindicated in infants age <1, postexposure prophylaxis is achieved with varicella-zoster immune globulin.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Chicken pox

answerChoiceList.choice: Recommend isolation and close observation alone

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Management of varicella in neonates and infants.

questionList.questionText:
A 72-year-old man comes to the hospital due to 12 hours of worsened shortness of breath and nonproductive cough.  He was in his usual state of health until 3 days ago, when he abruptly developed fever, headache, sore throat, runny nose, anorexia, and severe body aches.  The patient has no known sick contacts but spent a long time in a mall shopping for Christmas presents 5 days ago.  He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 28/min.  Oxygen saturation is 91% on 40% supplemental oxygen via mask.  Oropharyngeal examination shows mild pharyngeal erythema without exudates.  No lymphadenopathy or jugular venous distension is present.  Chest auscultation reveals scattered bilateral crackles and a fourth heart sound (S4) but no cardiac murmurs.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  There is no peripheral edema.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin13 g/dL
Platelets238,000/mm3
Leukocytes12,800/mm3

Chest x-ray reveals bilateral, diffuse reticular opacities.  Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Adults at high risk for influenza complications

  • Age ≥65
  • Women who are pregnant & up to 2 weeks postpartum
  • Underlying chronic medical illness (eg, chronic pulmonary, cardiovascular, renal, hepatic)
  • Immunosuppressed
  • Morbidly obese
  • Residents of nursing homes or long-term care facilities

Influenza virus is largely a winter infection that attacks the epithelium of the upper and lower respiratory tract.  Approximately 1-5 days after exposure, patients abruptly develop systemic (fever, malaise, myalgias, headache) and upper/lower respiratory (rhinorrhea, sore throat, nonproductive cough) symptoms.  Physical and laboratory examinations are often normal but may show pharyngeal erythema (without exudates) and mild alterations in leukocyte count (low early, high later).  Most patients recover spontaneously and completely within 1 week of symptom onset.  However, patients with advanced age (>65) and chronic medical illness (eg, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus) are far more likely to develop complications.

Pneumonia is the most common complication of influenza and is the result of either secondary bacterial infection (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae) or direct viral attack (influenza pneumonia).  Patients with primary influenza pneumonia typically have an acute worsening of symptoms (dyspnea, cough), leukocytosis (although <15,000/mm3), hypoxia, and bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray.  Hospitalization with supplemental oxygen support and antiviral (eg, oseltamivir) treatment is usually required.

Influenza may also cause complications in the muscle (myositis, rhabdomyolysis), heart (myocarditis, pericarditis), and central nervous system (encephalitis, transverse myelitis).

(Choice A)  Cytomegalovirus infection may cause a mononucleosis-like illness marked by fever, malaise, and absolute lymphocytosis.  Rhinorrhea is uncommon and pulmonary involvement rarely occurs unless there is significant immunocompromise (eg, HIV with CD4 <100/mm3).

(Choice B)  Group A Streptococcus infection can cause fever and sore throat with tonsillar exudates (pharyngitis).  This patient's pulmonary involvement, rhinorrhea, and myalgias indicate an alternate diagnosis.

(Choice D)  Pneumocystis pneumonia is almost always seen in patients with significant immunocompromise (eg, solid organ transplantation, HIV with CD4 <200/mm3) and is marked by fever, cough, dyspnea, and (often) chest x-ray evidence of bilateral interstitial infiltrates.  This condition is usually subacute and is not commonly associated with rhinorrhea and myalgias.

(Choices E and G)  Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and (less commonly) Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause secondary bacterial pneumonia in patients with influenza.  Patients with these infections have high fever, significant leukocytosis (>15,000/mm3), and lobar infiltrates on chest x-ray.  This patient with mild leukocytosis and bilateral, diffuse reticular infiltrates on chest x-ray likely has primary influenza pneumonia.

(Choice F)  Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection and influenza share many clinical symptoms, but patients with RSV often have wheezing and rarely (<1%) have diffuse, bilateral reticular infiltrates.

Educational objective:
Influenza is usually a self-limited infection marked by <1 week of systemic (fever, malaise, myalgias, headache) and respiratory (rhinorrhea, sore throat, nonproductive cough) symptoms.  Complications (eg, pneumonia) are common in patients with advanced age and chronic illness.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Influenza

questionList.questionText: A 3-year-old, previously healthy girl is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty swallowing.  The patient has had fever, chills, malaise, myalgias, and sore throat for a week.  Today, she is refusing to drink fluids and spits out any liquids given to her.  The patient has a history of small puncture wounds on her left forearm that the family noticed 2 months prior.  It is unclear how the wounds occurred, but the site was cleaned and dressed and has since healed completely.  Temperature is 40 C (104 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse is 144/min, and respirations are 34/min.  Examination shows an agitated, disoriented girl with copious drool and facial grimacing who frequently spits saliva.  There is numbness surrounding a small, healed scar on the left forearm.  The neck is supple with full range of motion.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Human rabies

Pathogenesis

  • Transmission of rabies virus by a bite from an infected mammal

Reservoir

  • United States: bats (most common), raccoons, skunks, foxes
  • Resource-limited countries: dogs

Clinical

features

Encephalitic

  • Hydrophobia & aerophobia (due to pharyngeal spasm)
  • Autonomic instability
  • Spasticity
  • Agitation & altered mental status

Paralytic

  • Ascending flaccid paralysis

Postexposure
prophylaxis*

  • Rabies immunoglobulin
  • Rabies vaccine series

Prognosis

  • Coma, respiratory failure & death within weeks

*In cases of a high-risk animal that cannot be tested or observed.

Rabies is a fatal, neurotropic viral disease transmitted via exposure to saliva from an infected animal through a bite.  In the United States, bats and racoons account for most human exposures.  Because bat teeth are small and needle shaped, many bites may go unnoticed, particularly if the patient is asleep, which likely occurred in this case.

The virus amplifies in muscle cells at the inoculation site and travels centrally within the nerves to reach the spinal cord, a process that can take several weeks.  Therefore, initial symptoms typically develop 1-3 months after exposure and are characterized by a nonspecific prodrome (eg, fever, chills, sore throat, malaise) lasting a few days; pain, tingling, and/or numbness of the bite wound, as seen in this patient, is highly suggestive of clinical rabies.

From the spinal cord, the virus spreads quickly to the brain then disseminates peripherally, particularly affecting muscles and other highly innervated areas (eg, salivary glands).  Therefore, most patients develop encephalitic symptoms, including the pathognomonic hydrophobia (ie, fear of liquids, refusal to drink) and aerophobia (ie, fear of drafts of air) due to pharyngeal spasms.  Dysautonomia (eg, hypersalivation), muscle contractions (eg, grimacing, opisthotonos), and fluctuating agitation are also common.  Almost all patients develop coma and die within weeks.

(Choices A and D)  Herpes simplex virus encephalitis is spread via close contact with an infected person's secretions and presents with fever, headache, seizure, and focal neurologic deficits.  West Nile virus (transmitted via mosquito bites) can present with nonspecific symptoms (eg, fever, myalgia) and meningitis/encephalitis.  Neither condition would explain this patient's hydrophobia, excessive drooling, facial grimacing, and wound paresthesia.

(Choice C)  Tetanus can be contracted through a bite but presents with trismus, which is not seen in this patient, who is able to open her mouth.  In addition, unlike rabies, tetanus symptoms develop within 3 weeks of exposure; this patient sustained wounds 2 months prior.

(Choice E)  Clostridium botulinum infection of a puncture wound can lead to wound botulism and classically causes symmetric descending weakness, which is not seen here.  In addition, wound botulism develops 1-2 weeks after exposure, whereas this patient's wound from 2 months prior is well healed.

Educational objective:
Rabies is a fatal, neurotropic viral disease transmitted to humans by exposure to saliva from an infected animal through a bite.  Paresthesia of the bite wound is characteristic, and after an incubation period of 1-3 months, patients develop encephalopathy, dysautonomia, and hydrophobia, followed by coma and death.

questionList.title: Rabies

Human rabies—Wyoming and Utah, 2015.
